summary: (over 100) 3 sestertii: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 169).

The denarii (Vespasian - Trajan) were found together with a bronze brooch in the main building of a villa rusticate, located between Altdorf and Jülich-Kirchberg, on the site of the Inden open pit mining site (Braunkohletagebau Inden).

The hoard was discovered in 1850 by a private person during a search quarry stones. The coins lay concealed without a discernible container in the wall aperture of a Roman cellar (Quintan- obere prätorische Straße)). The hoard is thought to have comprised 360-370 denarii. 280 of them are now in the collection of antiquities from Nassau, in Wiesbaden. Coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
A hoard of 10 aurei (Domitian - Antoninus Pius), found in the 1880s in Trier, in a small earthenware container; it was published in 1928 as part of the collection of Dr. Leopold Seligmann.
Several hundred denarii found with an iron jar. Only six provided data on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus.
14 denarii: Claudius I – Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
disposition: National museum, Prague, Czech Republic (11 coins)

summary: A large hoard of 1,500-2,000 coins: 508 republican coins are identified; all the emperors up to Hadrian are represented except Augustus.
Denarius hoard consisting of 14 denarii found with metal detectoring. Galba to Antoninus Pius.
Unknown originally number of coins. 50 denarii were sent to the Sankt Petersburg. Among issuers: Vespasiaen, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Commodus (AD 180-192).
7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180). Two other coins, one bronze and one bronze of the 4th century were handed together to the museum.
240 silver coins: 228 denarii, 2 drahms found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 8

summary: 22 denarii, part of a hoard: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).
6 bronze coins: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
4 silver denarii: Hadrian (Sabina), Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2562

summary: Originally 16 denarii, 15 preserved: Domitian - Septimius Severus(AD 193-211); silver weight: 42.63 g. (15 coins).
Two aurei depicting Lucius Verus (AD 161-169). No description. Callu-Loriot record these coins as single finds, however, same findspot, same coin issuer (quite rare).
646 denarii layed in the ground: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195). 152 coins of this find disappeared between 1907 and 1975.
The hoard comprised approximately 100 aurei from Nero to Hadrian. Only 7 were examined: Nero, Vespasian, Trajan 2, Hadrian 3.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Oviedo, Spain (7 coins)

summary: Two aurei, Domitian (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) found in sequential years, in the same forest. Close chronological range.

The hoard of 79 denarii (one Republican denarius; imperial coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius) and one Lycian drachm was found in 1882 during plowing of a court at Middels-Osterloog. The coins lay in a container.
The hoard comprised 65 bronze coins dated between 294-283 BC and AD 117-138.
410 denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 161-192).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2519

summary: Originally 390, 371 preserved: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver weight: 965.17 g.
(8-900) 52 aurei: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 172-175).
disposition: Collection Rockox (37 coins), in 17th century; collection Van Gestel (1 coin), in 17th century; collection Christine de Suède (non-identifiable)

summary: Hoard of 120 coins: 2 aurei, 118 denarii: Titus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museo de San Isidro, Los Orígenes de Madrid

summary: 235 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).
31 bronze coins: 22 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Hadrian
Hoard of 375 denarii. Only 7 coins were mentioned: Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Faustina II 3, Lucilla, Commode.
141 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192).

The hoard comprised 4 sestertii ranging from Trajan to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1957) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. Only 2 coins preserved, but descriptions of all of them exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (2 coins); lost (2 coins)

summary: A little more than 20 coins were found (only 11 known and recorded). The coins were found while leveling two tumuli revealing some 'depots' of denarii Trajan - Commodus (AD 181-182).

2nd century. Hoard of 8 coins recovered with a frag. of a bronze vessel, possibly its original container. The coins all exclusively 2nd C terminating with issue of Crispina (AD 177-183), though hoard may have been deposited in 3rd C AD.Rudling, D. 1982. The Romano-British farm on Bullock Down. In P. Drewett (ed.) The Archaeology of Bullock Down, Eastbourne, East Sussex.

A hoard of 111 Roman imperial denarii was found by five treasure hunters in 2013 in Chernivtsi region. Information about the find and photos of some of the coins of the hoard were published by one of the finders on January 20, 2014 on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity. According to the finder, the hoard was found late at night, but there is no more detailed information about the further circumstances of the find. Judging by the information from the treasure hunter, the bulk of the coins in the hoard were denarii of Vespasian, Trajan and Hadrian, although there was also a coin of Galba, several denarii of Nerva, and 10-12 coins of Antoninus Pius and Faustina (I or II). In the photographs posted with the hoard information, there are images of 26 whole and five fragments of denarii (Vespasian, Terva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius) – these were probably some of the coins that the informant found. The further fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown.
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 122 denarii from Otho to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 193. There were also 'some illegible issues' and three silver spoons.

In 1900 the Hanauer museum acquired 44 denarii from an antique dealer in Büdingen, which obviously belonged to a find. The coins were supposedly found in 1899 in Marköbel during the construction of a house. The coins are today no longer present in the Hanauer museum. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).
311 denarii and 1 drachm, ranging from Nero to Commodus (AD 187-188), found in a leather purse while cutting peat.

Four bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius), found on the Dowe-See estate on the Bullenteich in Braunschweig, next to other small Roman objects (bronze fibula, bronze ring, glass pearls, spindle whorl, etc.).
12 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 1 dupondius/as found stuch together in a layer of fire: Nero - Hadrian (AD 129-130).
Around 600 denarii; Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: In 1906, there were 355 coins in the Coin Room of the Royal Academy in Königsberg, 16 copies in the Museum of Prussia, Königsberg. The fate of the rest is unknown. Approximately 250 denars were melted down. Lost

summary: 270 coins. Only 10 sestertii are known: Trajan, - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Collection vicar Verstraete, Kortrijk, Belgium (c. 155 coins), in 1846; collection .C. Lefèvre,Brugge, Belgium (10 coins), in 1846

summary: The hoard comprised between 1,400 and 1,500 'copper' coins from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
The hoard comprised 9 aurei found near the 'Caserne' of Autun. The aurei dated from Vespasian to Faustina I, and may be just a small part of a more important hoard.
52 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
(52) 49 denarii found with a ceramic vessel of Carpic manufacture: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (post AD 141).
Three bronze coins in a small vessel: 1 sestertius Trajan, 1 AE Hadrian, 1 AE L. Aelius (AD 137-138).
Over 200 silver coins. 168 are known: 166 denarii, 2 drachms of Lycia: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).

The circumstances of discovery and the composition of the hoard were judged to be suspect. De Vesly questioned whether this hoard might actually have been stolen and assembled as a hoard. However, there is nothing to support this hypothesis. Found by a workman in a quarry in the Duclair forest: Nero - Hadrian (AD 125-128). Two or four coins are missing.
25 silver denarii were found along with a considerable amount of human bone, interpreted as being an indicator of a battlefield site.
Possibble hoard of unknown number of silver and bronze coins found within a cemetery. The only preserved coins are two denarii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120210: 1-2

summary: The hoard comprised 301 Alexandrian tetradrachms. 300 were of Nero with a single coin of Hadrian. They were acquired in Egypt by Dattari.
46 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
129 bronze coins (1 provincial) unknown denomination: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158)
The hoard comprised more than 400 worn coins including issues of Nero, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and Crispina.

An ensemble of 6 denarii (incl. Vespasian, Hadrian with Clementia on the reverse, 2 Antoninus, 2 Crispina), found during excavations at the broch of Lingro, 1870-71, in different parts of the outbuildings [i.e. of the broch], that may have come from a scattered hoard.
175 denarii: Republic – Hadrian (AD 134-138).
Seven bronze coins (asses): Trajan – Antoninus Pius (AD 140-144). The coins were placed in a cooking pot with lid together with seven clay lamps, type FORTIS.
Four denarii, unknown whether they were found together or were part of a larger hoard: Titus, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II, Crispina. Most likely
41 Alexandrian bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 164-165). Found during excavations .
disposition: Exhibited in London 1902, now in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: A Regensburg employee submitted 8 sestertii (Antoninus Pius to Commodus) to the prehistorical state collection. The coins were derived from a find of unknown size in Regensburg.
The hoard comprised a total of 22 denarii dating from the Republic to Antoninus Pius. There are no further details about the structure of the hoard.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (22 coins)

summary: 514 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Over 600 denarii found while digging up a grave. Only 6 pieces provide information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 179-180).
(49) 48 denarii: 35 republican, 13 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 101/102) .

The hoard was found at a natural spring and comprised votives (including numerous wooden statuettes) as well as '149 copper coins of Roman emprors'. 79 of these coins were identified. The others were illegible.
1,446 denarii found during construction activity: Republic - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 177-192).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (964 coins)

summary: 16 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 192).

The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel, which was recovered in fragments and comprised 228 denarii. Part of the hoard (estimated at 58 coins) was sold but the landowner kept 200 or 201 denarii from Nero to Marcus Aurelius.
Unknown original number of coins. 36 denarii were recovered: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
Around 400 denarii found with a clay pot. 338 coins are known: Nero - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (294 coins), Museum Sandomierz (8 coins), Museum Ostrowiec Świętokrzyski (12 coins), Poland

summary: 368 aurei: Nero to Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.

A hoard of 757 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver ingot was discovered by a treasure hunter on January 11, 2018 in the Lviv region. Information about the find, the silver ingot and a general photo of the bunch uncleaned coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on 11 and 12 January 2018. According to the finder, the hoard was discovered in the forest at a depth of 30-40 cm. Initially a few slipped coins were found, and then the rest of the hoard. Among the coins, a silver ingot (ca. 8.7x1.5 cm) and a fragment of pottery were found. Only photos of 17 coins and the silver ingot were published separately. The further fate of the hoard is unknown, however, most probably it was sold at the Violity auction. Coins: Nerva (1), Hadrian (4), Hadrian (Aelius) (1), Hadrian (Antoninus Pius) (1), Antoninus Pius (3), Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (1), Marcus Aurelius (3), Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (1), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (1), Commodus (1), no information (740).

The hoard comprised numerous copper-alloy vessels, a mirror, a folding seat, Samian ware cups and plates and six glass bottles, one of which contained 40 very worn sestertii and dupondii of Nerva, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.
13 denarii from a discovery in the surroundings of the city: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).

1590 bronze coins (1452 Dium, 47 koinon of Thessaly, 39 koinon of Macedonia, 13 Thessalonica, 7 Philippi, 2 Edessa, 2 Corinth, 1 Amphipolis, 1 Magydus, 1 Tralleis, 10 uncertain, and 15 Roman bronzes), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 2000). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
The hoard comprised 41 denarii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus.
150 coins, of which 10 sestertii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised 25 coins (23 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 1 Provincial bronze of Trajan of the Koinon of Cyprus), ranging from Titus to Antoninus Pius.
Originally circa 660 denarii, 290 coins were studied, 100 preserved: Titus - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 270.19 g. (100 coins).
Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 coins are kept in the History Museum in Iași: Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) 1.
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași, Romania (inv.nos. 680, 714/9, 744, 768, 774, 779)

summary: Seven sestertii found sealing a child burial in one of the house of C. Iulius Silvanus: Domnitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-152).
The hoard comprised 514 imperial bronze coins: Nero-Septimius Severus (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Altino, Italy; private collection; some lost

summary: In 2010 archaeological excavation of the northern part of Tyritake city-site (site XXVIII) a boxlike altar made of limestone tiles was found in Room I. Altar clearing uncovered two golden staters of Bosporus kings Eupator and Sauromates II, which are most likely to have been offerings to Dionysus. Sauromates II’s stater suggests dating offerings to Dionysus to AD 179 or a little later.
A small hoard of denarii (6+ specimens, Antoninus Pius - Pertinax), found in or around Apelstedt.
11 denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 181).
107 denarii were found in a ceramic vessel together with 6 silver bracelets (3 pairs), a plated silver brooch and glass beads. No further informationn
Unknown number of denarii. 5 pieces entered the museum collection in Kazanlak: Domitian 1, Trajan 4.
disposition: Museum of History, Kazanlak, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3994-3998

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel filled with sestertii, which were shared amongst the finders. After an investigation by the Gendarmarie, 59 were found. In 1980, illegal metal detecting on the site recovered a further 5 coins which are likely to be part of the hoard.
(90) 27 denarii: 7 republican, 20 imperial: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel.
A hoard of approx. 35 gold coins (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), scattered within a small space in fire debris of a destructed Roman house, found during work on the canalisation in the Leostrasse.
237 provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144). Two sacks found in a house during excavations.
Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2013 T096. Other PAS records associated with this hoard: DEV-269707
1 dupondius and 6 asses (Vespasian to Trajan) discovered beneath the concrete bedding for the flagstones at the south-eastern end of the basilica.
14 bronze coins: 10 dupondii, 4 asses: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-169).

13 Roman silver coins, presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, in 1781, all dug up 'with a great many more' in the muir (= moorland) of Linlithgow. These probably came from a find of 300, found in the Burrowmuir, deposited in an earthen urn.

A hoard of ca. 460 Roman silver denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius for 344 of them, the others are lost), found in an earthenware container 1 1/2 feet under the soil while removing stones ('Steineroden') in the heather, at Wassermühle on the Wingstberg.
Unknown originally number of denarii. Only 10 pieces are known: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 186-192).
The hoard was found in a burial which contained 'two middle bronzes of "Antoninus" and one of Faustina II, as well as a unidentified sestertius.
The hoard comprised 24 bronze coins of the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/6).
65 Roman silver coins found a small urn or earthern vessel, while removing the root of a tree near the house of Mr. Burke, at Beaconsfield. The coins ranged from Vespasian to Faustina.

A hoard of 20 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Commodus, but no details known for 12 coins) was found between 1880 and 1890 in a glass bowl, between the city and the railroad, directly southeast of the confluence of the Horst- and Totengraben.
5 or 6 silver denarii. The coins were originally corroded together. Three coins were separated, leaving a stack of either 2 or 3 denarii.
764 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111). Together were found four silver earrings and 3 silver bracelets found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos M II 3331-4094 (764 coins)

summary: A small hoard of six Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian — Hadrian (AD 117-138) was discovered by treasure hunter in 2014, possibly in Rivne region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on November 28, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the find was discovered about two years ago before publication in a ploughed field. The coins were collected from a small area, but he did not probe to sondage on the place of find, assuming that he would find new finds after each ploughing. However, he has not found any new coins at the site in two years. All coins are equally well preserved (minimal worn) and close chronologically, which allows them to be considered as one deposit. In December 2016 and January 2018, the coins were sold on Violity auction. Coins: Vespasian (Titus) (1), Titus (2), Hadrian (3).

During excavations on the site of the ancient town of Lyka, a hoard of 7 provincial coins of the Koinon of Macedonia (Hadrian - Faustina II) was found in trench II, in a very burnt layer, near a cencer and in the same depth with it and nearby silver votive plaques with relief representation. These have been interpreted as remnants of a ritual act, a "sealed group" of votive offerings in honour of a deity.

Approx. 200 Roman silver coins found by chance as a waggon had crushed the jar that contained them. One of the accounts relating to this find gives a list of emperors: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, the two Antonines, Faustina and L. Aelius Verus.
3,728 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2599-3353 (3626 coins)

summary: In 1962 an excavator found a jar with 7 aurei, 1346 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), and 4 Lycian drachms (Domitian - Trajan), while building the foundations of the new building for the paper mill factory at Stockstadt.
disposition: The majority of the find was sent to Aschaffenburg Municipal Museum

summary: 105 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown initial number of coins. 244 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175)
12 coins: 1 denarius, 11 sestertiiTrajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m westward from the hoard Koropie 2008 1. Together were found a bronze brooch and a horn shape bronze ring
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: 271 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero – Commodus (AD 184-185).

A hoard of 178 Roman denarii, ranging from Marc Antony to Hadrian, found at the bottom of an earthenware jar in 1934, in a field south of Louth, Lincolnshire. Among the coins, one hybrid of Domitian with a reverse of Hadrian (now in the BM).
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: 36 aurei: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 103-111) found hidden in the wall of a Roman house.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 denarii, 1 drachm of Dyrrachium and 1 denarius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) were recovered.
Hoard of more than 200 denarii. Only 10 were documented: Hadrian (Aelius Caesar) - Pertinax (AD 193).
20 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only eight pieces were recovered: 2 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 3 asses: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum History and Archaeology, Constanța, Romania

summary: 51 denarii: 16 republican, 35 imperial: Republic - Hadrian (AD 119-122). Together was found a Dacian silver bracelet.
Six coins of Alexandria: Nero 1, Vespasian 2, Hadrian 2, Lucius Verus 1. No information about site or circumstances.
Eight sestertii found in Pot Ridings Wood.
8 denarii, ranging from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius, found on the north bank of the Tay at Inchyra, east of Perth.

A hoard of at least 105, possibly up to 115, denarii found at the end of December 1930, of which only 105 are still identified in the records of Rabat Museum. Chatelain, the original excavator, listed 114 coins in the find, including two coins of Juba II, one of Nero, one of Galba, nineteen of Vespasian, seven of Titus, twenty-three of Domitian, three of Nerva, forty-eight of Trajan and ten of Hadrian. However it is clear that Chatelain misidentified two of the Republican denarii as coins of Juba II. The next publication of the hoard, by Ruhlmann, came in 1933. This list largely agrees with the records kept by Rabat Museum, but includes ten extra coins, taking the total up to 115, which must now be regarded as lost. The missing coins listed by Ruhlmann are as follows: one Republican denarius, one denarius of Vespasian, two denarii of Domitian, five denarii of Trajan and one Hadrianic denarius. There are no further details concerning the types of these coins, because Ruhlmann only published in detail the nine latest specimens from the find. The whole hoard was contained in a hollow bracelet and was probably buried circa 122.
The hoard comprised 11 bronze coins dated between 175-164 BC and AD 117-138.
Two denarii: Antoninus I (Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius.
235 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 235 were documented: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). Weight: 597.2g (196 coins).
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia (collection Iversen); University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (36 coins)

summary: In 1857/8 at least 11 denarii ranging from Vespasian to Hadrian were found during building work in the basement of a house.
Five aurei found in grave no. 6: Nero, Galba, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found 11 drachms of Gotarze and 3 denarii of Augustus.
The total number of coins is apparently 1067 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 152-153).

320 D: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180): Discovered in an onion field after it had been ploughed. The finder carefully collected the coins together, but discarded fragments of the pottery container. Found whilst harvesting onions in a field in the north-western part of the village, next to the road leading to Gruia.

The hoard was found in the foundation trench of a Gallo-Roman wall. It comprised 43 denarii from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius as Caesar (AD 148/149). It may originally have been placed in a small box, as fragments of copper-alloy scrap were found in association with the coins.
110 denarii. Only 79 were recovered: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193); silver weight: 202.4-323.4 g.
76 gold coins found in the nineties: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD
11 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown number of aurei and denarii: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) (AD 145-161).
307 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Maramureș, Baia Mare, Romania

summary: 14 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175); silver weight: 22.67 g (8 coins).
Two denarii of Hadrian (AD 134-138).

The hoard comprised 50 Roman coins which were thought to be bronzes. There is no further information on denominational composition. It was found on communal heathland and pasture, at a very shallow depth. The majority of the coins were collected together by M. Auvray, mayor of Aclou.
Seven denarii found under a pile of Roman bricks: Trajan – Septimius Severus (AD 197).
Two sestertii found together and recorded as a hoard in the HER. The coins could not be closely identified and were returned to the finder as they did not meet the criteria for Treasure.
The hoard comprised 44 coins dated between the 4th-3rd century BCE and the reign of Hadrian (AD 117-138).

Three denarii of Hadrian, found around 1896 on the Debra, a plateau approx. 1.5 km northeast of Rudolstadt, near Debrahof, on Rudolstadt-Teichweiden road; the coins could form part of a larger hoard of denarii.

The hoard comprised either a) a ceramic vessel containing several hundred sestertii of Nero to Marcus Aurelius. b) two ceramic vessels found on separate occasions containing 60 and 110 coins respectively.
About 700 Roman coins were found in a ford in the river Pettarel near Carlisle in 1762. Coins seem to range from Nero to Faustina. A list of 64 of them (1 aureus, 62 denarii and 1 sestertius) exists.
(700) 612 silver coins: 610 denarii, 2 drachmas: Nero-Commodus (AD 184-185).
6 denarii to AD 161 - "hoard 2" Davies 2000. From an occupation layer in range 3 of structure 1, Pickfords Garage site. Scattered in a small area with no evidence of a container.
257 denarii found with an amphora: Republic – Commodus (AD 191-192).
2 denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found while ploughing.
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 722 'bronzes'. It has been suggested that they were sestertii dating from the reign of Hadrian to Commodus. Found close to the brickworks.
The hoard comprised 10 bronze coins: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 103-111). Weight: 68.27 g.
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Italy

summary: 23 denarii: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 160-161).
disposition: Museum of Dacian and Roman Civilisation, Deva, Romania

summary: It comprised 210 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel, notably from Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and one of the Faustinas.
ca. 80 sestertii and dupondii, but not all of them are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised approximately 200 'small Roman bronzes' of the Antonine period, most of which were well preserved. Unfortunately, an acid bath rendered them indecipherable.
The hoard was found in a female burial and contained a box or casket containing 18 Antonine coins, earrings, brooches, a belt buckle and a terracotta figurine in the shape of a small horse.

A hoard of 9 provincial coins from Athens (periods VB and VC) and one sestertius of Commodus. The coins were excavated in 1936 in front of the north end of the Stoa of Attalos (grid P 7). When found, several of the coins were stuck together, suggesting that all ten were originally put away in a purse.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only five coins are recorded. Uncertain whether they were found together.
disposition: Museu de Martins Sarmento, Guimarães. Portugal

summary: 11 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 105).
Hoard of 1000 denarii of the Antonines and 6 aurei of Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.
A concealed hoard of 22 aurei of 'Nero, Hadrian and the Antonines' found c. 1888. It is believed that the hoard was from Wanborough / Durocornovium, but this is not certain.
Around 1,460 denarii - a number established based on an average weight of 3 g/coin (4.510 g)- comprising Republican issues to Commodus (AD 1180-192). 19 coins entered the collection of the Ermitage.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia (19 coins)

summary: 18 denarii found on a field: Otho - Hadrian (AD 128-136).
Around 100 hundred Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii/asses): Domitian - Didius Julianus (AD 193)
disposition: Museum of Chambéry, France (partially). private collections: Conte, Faudrain, Fivel etc.

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 40 denarii entered Museum Collection in Opole in 1973:
disposition: Municipal Museum Opole, Poland (40 coins in 1973)

summary: Originally 17 denarii, 16 preserved: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 44.65 g. (16 coins). Together were also found: 1 gold bracteate, 1 gold finger ring, 2 neck-rings of bronze with silver mountings, 2 somewhat smaller bronze rings, 1 bronze clasp, 1 bronze strap-end, several bronze spirals, 1 amber bead, 2 coral beads.

After the war in a building excavation pit, 30 Roman denarii (Galba to Lucilla) were found in an amber-glazed jar from the sixteenth century, wrapped individually in a linen cloth. It is likely that a Roman hoard was unearthed in the Renaissance, and has now been found for the second time.

Discovered during agricultural work near the village, on a field belonging to the peasant Grigory Radzevich. The hoard included 21 denarii (Trajan-Commodus) and silver items (ingot and four rings). The hoard was sent to the Imperial Archaeological Commission in St. Petersburg, where the coins were identified by J. Iversen; then transferred to the State Hermitage
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: 7 coins found stuck together: 4 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 1 sestertius, 1 as: Mark Antony - Hadrian (AD 121-122).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.no. CC 315/90)

summary: 120 denarii. 32 were donated to the History Museum in Silistra: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A Roman coin hoard of 80-100 denarii was unearthed in Samenheim. The precise find location and circumstances are not further ascertainable. The bulk of the find is lost. Only 20 denarii, ranging from Nero to Hadrian, now part of a private collection, are preserved. It is possible that these 20 coins may represent the full chronological coverage of the original find.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 coins provide information on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).

The hoard comprised 60 silver coins from the reigns of Nero to Hadrian, deposited during the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-136). These coins were: 42 denarii (Vespasian to Hadrian), 10 tetradrachms and 1 tridrachm from Antioch (Nero to Trajan), 6 tridrachms and 1 drachm of Trajan from Arabia.
Two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus/Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). Militky considers a misidentification of this hoard with the one Dobřichov-Plaňany (PLAŇANY 1892).
Hoard of 89 coins of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalces, Eupator.
The hoard comprised 48 sestertii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius and was buried around AD 170.
53 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Circumstances of discovery are unknown.
The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing approximately 50 sestertii of Trajan, Hadrian and Antoninus Pius. The hoard was found on the Mortrais farm.

Around 400 denarii found during archaeological excavations. Only 25 denarii provide information on issuers: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together with the coins was also a silver bar of 155g and, possible, a brooch.
disposition: Friends of Science Society, Poznań, Poland (25 coins)

summary: Uncertain whether the coins were found together or single finds. Only four coins were provided with some information.
Originally, 47 coins. 33 denarii were described: Vitellius - Trajan (AD 103-111).
228 denarii: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (Crispina) (AD 177-191).

Arm purse containing 63 coins (3 aurei and 60 denarii), ranging from the late Republic to Hadrian, found while quarrying stones. Each of the gold coins was wrapped up in a separate piece of greenish leather or vellum, which was still quite tough and strong.
disposition: Clayton Memorial Museum, Chesters (purse). The coins are said to have been given to the Blackgate Museum, Newcastle, but have not been located there

summary: 556 denarii found with a bronze vessel: Trajan - Septimius Sverus (AD 193). Silver weight: 1,694g.
Around 1,200 aurei (according to Savio/Cavagna): Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Reported to have contained thousands of coins. The main part had been dispersed before the rest was confiscated.
The hoard comprised 13 silver coins dated between AD 62/3 and AD 123.
The hoard comprised 2 aurei, more than 400 denarii and some bronze coins and was found in association with a grave: Vespasian Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown initial number of coins: 28 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); silver weight: 54.2-84.4g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.no. M I 233-250

summary: 28 bronze coins found near a skeleton: 27 provincial coins minted on Cyprus (uncertain mint under Augustus and Tiberius; Koinon of Cyprus for Claudius, Vespasian, and Trajan) and 1 sestertius of Trajan (AD 114-117).
10 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Hadrian 3, Antoninus Pius 4, Faustina I 2, Lucilla 1.

177 denarii with portraits of emperors from Vespasian to Trajan and two denarii of Mark Antony's 'legionary' series. The denarii were found with a ceramic vessel. The metal analyses, fresh minting loo-alike state of preservation for the large majority of the coins as well as the overweight for most of the coins reveal a 'hoard' of ancient counterfeited coins. The dating of coin type is based on the genuine prototype, otherwise, it looks that they were all minted in/after AD 116.
disposition: Museum of National Union, alba Iulia, Romania

summary: Denarius hoard consisting of 17 denarii. Vespasian to Commodus.

Accidentally discovered by schoolboy Leonid Ryshchuk in 1974. The hoard was found on the territory of the Lyshchitsy peat enterprise, on the northern edge of the peat bog, near the bridge across the ditch, 250 m south of the field, south of the cemetery of the village of Ogorodniki. According to the discoverer, the total number of coins ranged from 350 to 500 pieces. Most of the coins were taken by local residents and collectors, only 48 denarii have survived from this find (transferred to the Brest Regional Local History Museum). In 1974, at the hoard find spot, L. Pobol carried out excavations, another 63 coins were discovered (transferred to the Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus). 5 coins from the hoard are in the private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk. A total of 116 coins are known: 115 denarii (Nero-Marcus Aurelius) and one imitation of denarius.
disposition: Brest Regional Local History Museum (48 coins); Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus (63 coins); private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk (5 coins)

summary: A probable hoard of 3 sestertii and one 1 denarius (Vespasian and Hadrian) found among charcoal and other occupation refuse in Room 25. Their date range suggests a hoard, but this cannot be said for certain as their exact depositional context was not recorded.
A hoard containing nearly 100 silver denarii from the period of Trajan and Hadrian was unearthed between Trostadt and Siegritz.
The hoard comprised 117 sestertii and 43 dupondii or asses from Vespasian to Commodus with a tpq of AD 190. It was found under the sixth step of a staircase discovered under a lime kiln.
Unknown originally number of coins. 27 denarii are kept at the Institute of Archaeology in Bucharest: Trajan – Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology ”V. Parvan”, Bucharest, Romania (27 coins).

summary: 255 denarii found and sent to the Ministry of Finance. The coins were found with pieces of an urn during the removal of stones from a field.
Hoard of 40 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 24 coins were documented: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 140).

The details of the hoard are not well known. Found in 1871 it passed possession multiple times and was eventually split. Originally 387 silver coins were found, and one gold piece, along with several urns. Only 12 pieces are described: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla Augusta).
The hoard comprised a small iron safe containing two aureii and a variety of jewellery.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France

summary: 47 denarii. Only 5 coins are kept in the Museum of Assen: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 176)
Hoard of 183 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown original number of coins. 15 pieces are known: 14 denarii, 1 dupondius: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic (7 coins); Collection Červinkova (8 coins)

summary: Coins found in sarcophagus no. 905: 34 gold and silver coins: 3 Aurei: Nero 2, Hadrian 1; 14 denarii: Augustus 12,Uncertain (Augustus?) 2; 1 hemidrachm of Hadrian, and 16 drachms of Gotarzes II.
11 denarii found in a purse (vanished): Mark Antony - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: Centrul de Studii de Istorie și Arheologie, Timișoara, Romania; inv.no. 237/2005

summary: Unknown quantity of bronze coins. Three sestertii: Claudius I, Nero, Marcus Aurelius were offered to the Regional History Museum in Ruse.
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria

summary: A hoard of 296 denarii (Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius), found by a grave-digger in Allerton Bywater churchyard.
30 sestertii found stuck together in a Roman edifice: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD162-163).
disposition: Museo de Arqueología de Álava, Spain

summary: 200-150 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 48 denarii are known today: Nero – Hadrian (AD 125-128).
28 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-139). Probably a hoard, found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: Some 650 provincial bronze coins of Alexandria: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150). 'Intact hoard belonging to "qualche officina monetaria".

Upwards of 600 Roman denarii were found in 1851 in a field that was formerly a deep bog. The coins were all lying close together as if they had been enclosd in a bag. Also found at the same spot were an iron sword and an imperfect silver ornament thought to have been the crest of a helmet. A detailed account of 104 coins is given in 1852 and a further 26, found in a moss at Kirkness (Kinross) in 1851, were reported in 1934 and published in 1939. Coins range from Mark Antony to Septimius Severus.
The hoard comprised 31 sestertii, stacked one on top of the other, suggesting that they may have originally been packed in a tube or similar which has not survived: Nerva - Commodus (AD 189).
Penhallurick (2009, 245 no. 251) records a metal detector find of 9 sestertii found in an area of about 50 square metres in the same field. Considered to be part of a scattered hoard.
12 denarii (Hadrian and Antoninus Pius) found among charcoal, animal bone, and other debris inside the furnace next to Turret 1.
Grup of two denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161); silver weight: 5.52 g.
The sculptor Zanda of Desulo discovered a deposit of Roman bronze coins, near the church of San Pietro. One of them belongs to Faustina I and one to Lucilla.
15 of the sestertii from a larger hoard were identified by S. Bottin. The hoard was originally located in Bellaing in error.
(c. 215) 199 bronze coins: 194 sestertii, 5 dupondii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 191).
14 denarii: Domitian 3; Nerva 3; Trajan 6; uncertain (Domitian or Trajan) 1; Hadrian 1 (AD 117-138).
171 coins: 169 denarii,1 sestertius, 1 dupondius: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-159).
disposition: Balaton Museum, Keszthely (91 coins); private collection (72 coins), Hungary

summary: A hoard of four aurei: Nero, Trajan 2, Antoninus Pius for Faustina I (Diva).
disposition: Madras Museum, Chennai except for Trajan coins

summary: Two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 183).
Circa 100 Roman coins, silver and bronze. Only, 2 denarii of Antoninus Pius and Faustina I and 5 bronze coins (Vespasian to Trajan) were known.
124 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-189); silver weight: 43.80 g. (16 coins).
Hoard of 17 denarii (Mark Antony - Augustus) and 29 sestertii (Nerva - Hadrian) (AD 117-138).
Unknown originally number of denarii. 10 coins were seen: Vespasian 2, Trajan 4, Antoninus Pius 1, Marcus Aurelius 3. Possible, part of the same hoard with Strunga II and III.
Two denarii found together: Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius.
Three Roman bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius Caesar) were found together in a field, inside an old foundation wall.

The hoard comprised 12 aes coins (sestertii and dupondii) ranging from Domitian to Marcus Aurelius Caesar. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 5/1966) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (12 coins)

summary: Large hoard of silver coins. Only 7 denarii are kept in the museum of Pleven: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1452 1-7

summary: The hoard comprised 45 silver tetradrachms from Claudius I to Antoninus Pius. It is not clear whether the coins represent a complete hoard or part of a hoard.
500 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). TR POT XX IMP IIII COS III
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; circa 250 coins, inv.no. 853 1-128

summary: The hoard comprised 65 sestertii from Domitian to Commodus (AD 180-192). All the coins were very worn. Fragments of a ceramic vessel were found in association with the coins suggesting it was originally placed inside a pot.

Four gold coins found in a stone sarcophagus during excavations: Vespasian, Titus, Hadrian 2. Together were found four denarii: Augustus, Trajan, Hadrian, Faustina I. Together were found gold and silver jewellery, vessels, glass objects.

A hoard of 161 aurei and 4 denarii was discovered on the site of 29 Klagenfurter Str. in Villach. Four aurei were initially discovered before a supervised excavation at the site uncovered the rest of the coins. Of the 161 aurei, only 100 issues dating from Nero to Septimius Severus have been properly catalogued. The four denarii have all been catalogued: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 194-197).
disposition: Museum Der Stadt Villach (115 aurei and 4 denarii); private collection (42 aurei)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Only 11 denarii are known: Vespasian 2, Titus 1, Nerva 2, Trajan 3, Hadrian 3.
50 denarii found in the debris from a house foundation: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169).
disposition: Kärntner Landsmannschaft, Klagenfurt, Austria (46 coins); private collection (2 coins), lost (unknown number)

summary: 8 aurei: Nero - Antoninus Pius: M. Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 140-161)
26 sestertii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
Six aurei Possible part of a larger hoard.
Around 500 denarii. Only three are known from Domitian and Trajan.
disposition: Muzeum Archeologiczne i Etnograficzne w Łodzi, Poland (3 coins)

summary: A hoard of ancient coins, including a tetradrachm of Thassos and a denarius of Faustina I found with a ceramic vessel.
126 bronze coins:120 sestertii, 5 dupondii, 1 as: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD. Only 73 coins are kept in the museums' collections.
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt; Stadt Museum Villach, Austria. (73 coins)

summary: A hoard of more than 3000 coins was found opposite the church in Baarlo in 1830. More than 3000 coins (32 gold and the rest in silver) remained with banker Wolters. Further data is missing. Description is known for 5 coins. The first publication, in 1838, mention coins from Augustus to the Antoninians.
50 denarii ranging from the 2nd century BC Republic coins to Trajan, and including one plated specimen, found in a wooden building from the late 2nd century AD.
Hoard of denarii dispersed among locals. 88 denarii entered museums' collections. Six denarii can be entered at coin level: Antoninus Pius 1, Lucius Verus 1, Faustina II 3, Commodus 1.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (8 coins), Lublin (60 coins), Poland; Local museum, Lutsk (20 coins), Ukraine.

summary: Unknown number of bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus/Pertinax (AD 193).
Unknown number of Roman denarii, only 3 coins are known: Trajan 2, Hadrian.
disposition: Collection of Antonín Hofmeister (an archivist, 1945), Josefov, now missing.

summary: 35 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162).

A number (possibly 150) of Roman silver coins (possibly Nero - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius), found in the vicinity of the Herren-Holz, a quarter of an hour north of Spahn, lying on a mound of earth.
(8) 5 sestertii: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151)
Unknown originally number of coins. Most likely there is just one hoard found here and 36 denarii are known: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing at least 11 coins (10 sestertii and 1 dupondius) found during construction work. The pot and 11 coins were given to the Museum Laufen, where, ca. 2014, only these 11 coins could be identified: Domitian (1 coin), Trajan (1 coin), Hadrian (5 coins), Antoninus Pius (1 dupondius), M. Aurelius/L. Verus (1 coins), Commodus (1 coin), Crispina (1 coin).
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 63 coins were recovered, 62 denarii, 1 drachm: Vitellius – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).

The hoard comprised several hundred Roman coins (the majority being sestertii) contained in a wooden box. The hoard was found 2 or 300 metres from the conciergerie of the Hypogeum on the left towards the water tower.

The hoard comprised 2 denarii (Trajan, Hadrian) and 25 aes coins ranging from Domitian Caesar to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. 20 coins are preserved today, and reliable descriptions of the other ones exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (20 coins); lost (7 coins)

summary: Five denarii (Vespasian - Commodus Caesar), found together on the premises of the Pipinsburg (a megalithic hillfort of Viking times), close to Sievern.
162 sestertii and 1 as. The origins of this hoard is doubtful. It is also possible that it contains 2 sestertii from Marcus Aurelius and 2 imitations of a double sestertius from Postumus.
Hoard of nine aurei found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 3, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 4 (AD 177-178).
The hoard comprised 6 Roman Provincial coins: Dion (2 Trajan, 1 Hadrian), Thessalonica (1 Trajan, 1 pseudo-autonomous Antoninus Pius), found in grave 7 in Sevasti.
13 denarii found in a mound next to ceramic vessels: Antoninus Pius - Commodus(AD 180).
disposition: Frisian Museum, Leeuwarden (FML A 1129-1141), 2 coins lost.

summary: A hoard of 8 complete and 1 halved Roman provincial copper alloy coins (Antioch, Beroea, Laodicea, uncertain) from the reigns of Trajan and Antoninus Pius, found at Assur, iC6V, West, 50 cm below the surface of the hill.

11 AR denarii to AD 122. Latest coin is type of Hadrian-Fortuna referring to the departure of the emperor on his great expedition, AD 121-5. RIC assigns date range of AD 119-122.Addenda of 3 AR denarii to 117 in 2014 included here.
100 coins of which one bronze coin of Marcus Aurelius/Commodus for Crispina (Augusta) (AD 178-183).
disposition: Private collection and museum Eindhoven, Netherlands

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 46 tetradrachms and 200-350 denarii of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
disposition: L. Hamburger (British Museum); Montagu Collection; J. Evans; Kelsey Museum of Archaeology in Ann Arbor, Michigan; Detroit Institute of Arts

summary: 29 coins of unknown metal from "the 4th consulate of Vespasian to the 4th year of reign of Antoninus Pius " (AD 149.
4 denarii up to Commodus found in an arm purse.
Hoard of 190 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Republic (?) - Hadrian.
The hoard comprised approximately 10 tetradrachms and 35 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
92 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver bracelet.
7 bronze coins: 2 dupondii, 5 asses: Claudius I - Trajan (AD 101-102)
3200 silver coins found with bronze cauldron: 3197 denarii, 3 drachmas Lycia: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161) . 10.8 kg
disposition: Museum ”Dr. Molnár István”, Cristuru Secuiesc, Romania (1965)

summary: Over 40 Roman bronze coins, nummi of the Constantius II and the Houses of Valentinian I and of Theodosius I. Unearthed in 1888 by villagers digging a grave. No further details were reported. Bell, the then Archaeological Commissioner, was able to secure 40 pieces. The coin types were: Constantius II: fel temp reparation (falling horseman). House of Valentinian I: concordia auggg (Roma or Constantinopolis). House of Theodosius: salus reipublicae (victory/captive); virtus exerciti (emperor/victory); gloria Romanorum (two emperors).
The hoard comprised an unknown number of coins of which 24 denarii, including 11 Republican issues and 13 imperial issues from Vitellius to Antoninus Pius were recorded.
16 sestertii: Trajan 13, Hadrian 3 (AD 121-122).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 13625-13640

summary: Hoard of 300-400 denarii. Only two coins are documented: Trajan, Antoninus Pius.
A an aureus of Commodus and an imitation were acquired by Nagpur Museum.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 400 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Vespasian to Commodus. Most were very worn.
(21) 19 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 1 as: Trajan - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
A bronze jug containing 160 aurei, found on site 29 in Corbridge. Two bronze coins were found filling the narrow neck of the jug, where they had been placed, to act as a stopper to the narrow neck.
7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in an Iron Age warrior grave.
Unknown initial number of coins. 91 denarii in the Regional History Museum in Pleven: Otho - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 975 1-70

summary: Seven bronze coins: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 152-153) found secreted in a wall of a vaulted storage room during excavation of a granary.
The hoard comprised 'more than 500 coins of uncertain denomination and type' but including issues from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192).
324 denarii: M. Antony - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)
204 aurei found with a ceramic vessel, 97 pieces studied: Nerva - Commodus.
Hoard containing, among others, an aureus of Antoninus Pius for Faustina I (Diva) and an imitation of Tiberius aureus.
55 bronze coins with unknown findspot except for the mention north Portugal
50 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Around 200 denarii. Among them issues of Nero, Vitellius, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.
Circa 300 denarii were discovered while plowing. Denarii of Antoninus Pius and Commodus were mentioned.
A hoard of around 270 copper coinage, only 229 were recovered and identified: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Split, Croatia; partly dispersed

summary: 274 coins: 75 sestertii, 117 dupondii, 74 asses, 7 dupondii/asses, 1 bronze medallion: Gaius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-176). Together with the coins were found: 2 silver pans, 1 silver plate, silver wire bracelet.
More than 100 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The latest coins are from Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

IARCH record for a hoard of 30 denarii found between 1985 and 1992. The latest coins are two of Lucius Verus and Divus Antoninus both dated to AD 161 and an undated coin of Faustina II. This might suggest deposition in the earlier part of the reign of Marcus Aurelius. See WMID-1AC648 for full details and images. One of the coins of Trajan is a small fragment.
6 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II (AD 161-180)

A hoard of 47 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161) was discovered at the end of 2021 in Lviv region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting, by user Mikhail Tabachko (Михаил Табачко) on December 14, 2021. The finder reported only that the coins were found together somewhere in the Lviv region. The coins are well preserved. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
72 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
83 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
126 bronze coins: 88 sestertii, 9 dupondii, 8 asses, 1 provincial coin; 20 bronze coins unknown denomination: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 154-161).
disposition: Hungarian National Museum, Budapest, Hungary (1897); inventory list no. 460/1896

summary: 55 denarii found with a ceramic jar: Galba - Commodus (AD 189). Found one meter from STARYIE VALKY 2013 2, practically, one hoard.
116 coins - 3 aurei and 113 denarii - found together during the archaeological excavations
Two denarii found on a field by chance: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Antoninus Pius (Divus).
Circa 500 denarii, of which 264 were brought after 1873 to the National Hungarian Museum in Budapest. 168 coins were identified: Nero – Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (AD 141-161).
A hoard of denarii, found in a field from 1962 until 2001. FMRD lists 67 coins (Trajan - Pertinax).
The hoard comprised six bronze coins dated between AD 70-81 and AD 117/118. It was deposited inside the hollow part of a door frame in the tepidarium of a Roman bathhouse. Votive role?
Hoard of 314 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

The hoard comprised a double deposit within a single room of a building. In one corner of the room, there were four coins, including one of Marcus Aurelius, 1 of Lucilla and 2 of Commodus. In the opposite corner, there was an identical deposit.
HER record of a first century hoard found on Sheringham Beach along with remains of a ceramic container, exposed through cliff erosion. Only 5 coins were examined but the hoard was much larger.
13 denarii found in a room of a Germanic house: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
The hoard comprised 9 figurines, 1 patera and 7 bronze coins from Vespasian to Commodus.

Portions of this hoard were acquired by the ANS in 1911 and 1912, totaling 783 coins. 451 of these could be identified in the museum's collection, including 448 denarii, Vespasian to Commodus (AD 183-184) and 3 Cypriote didrachms of Vespasian. This hoard is said to have been discovered in Larnaka, though no details are available.
More than 800 originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 441 coins: 406 sestertii, 29 dupondii, 5 asses, 1 AE provincial: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (443 coins); Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (1 coin).

summary: Six coins found while extracting stone: Antoninus Pius 2, Faustina I 1, Commodus, 1 uncertain. No further information.
Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 350 coins were basically examined : Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Balaton Museum Keszthely (312 coins); Magyar Nemzeti Muzeum, Budapest (38 coins), Hungary

summary: Six aurei found in grave of Asfagur: Titus, Trajan, Hadrian 4 (AD 117-138).
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 4 coins were documented: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Commodus.
The hoard comprised 60 silver coins and some bronzes, including one of Faustina I.
The hoard was found in a void within a Roman wall and comprised 5 sestertii: 1 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius, 2 Marcus Aurelius, 1 Faustina II (AD 147-176).
In 1853 not far from the Oste river during earthworks three bronze coins (Marcus Aurelius) were found at a depth of 10 feet. Pit holes and other remains indicate a settlement.
In 1937 a small hoard of 9 sestertii (Trajan - Commodus) was found in the north of Faimingen in the foundation walls of a Roman building, between the Roman road and the contemporary road.
37 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927 and 1928, now, in a private collection: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 101.03 g.
disposition: Private collection Axel O. Larsson, Stockholm

summary: Hoard consists of 70 Roman denarii (26 studied, 1 solidus): Vespasian - Didius Julianus (AD 193). Together with these coins were found: a solidus of Constantius II (Nicomedia/Cyzicus/Antioch, AD 340-355) as a pendant, two gold pendants slightly different in size, two belt buckles: one silver and one bronze, and a group of 13 silver pendants from a necklace.
166 bronze coins: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Asturias, Oviedo, Spain

summary: 70 imperial bronze coins of poor state of conservation. Among them, issues of Antoninus Pius 12, Faustina I 1.
HER record of 30 to 40 denarii from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius found in the mid 1970s following dredging of the Little Ouse and not apparently recorded elsewhere.
72 denarii: Antoninus Pius – Commodus (AD 180-192).
10 denarii: Trajan – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162).
disposition: NPÚ-ÚOP Pardubice, Náchod Castle collection, Czech Republic (inv.nos. 2.920, 3.016-3.023).

summary: Circa 300 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while metal detecting. At the moment, 17 pieces are available for description: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-160).

The hoard comprised a 'ceramic vessel containing approximately 20 kilos of Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii and asses). Of 872 examples, only 423 were identified.': Vespasian - Septimius Severus for Clodius Albinus (Caesar) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museé de Rouen, France (600 coins) (Inv. III, 2, p. 56, no. 1921)

summary: Iron Age British silver and copper-alloy coins, Roman Republican silver denarii, Roman imperial denarii, Roman copper-alloy coins, totalling 465 specimens. The assemblage seems to constitute continuous votive deposition rather than a hoard.

5 bronze coins (Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius), found dispersed across the excavation area. It is possible that an Augustan as (RIC 436) also belonged to this hoard. One interpretation is that these coins could have belonged to a small 'hoard' (or purse) that was later scattered across the site, though admittedly there is no sign of other artefacts being moved around the site.

The first 20 (?) denarii from the hoard were discovered by schoolchildren in 1968, eight of them were transferred to the Coin Room of the Belarusian State University. V. Ryabtsevich tried to establish the place where the hoard was found, but to no avail. In the first hoard's publication the village of Žukievičy was named as its location. After that, at the hoard's place, amateurs conducted further searches for it. Separate denarii were found, two of which (Trajan and Antoninus Pius) were transferred by V. Kakareka to the Coin Room of the Belarusian University. The rest of the hoard was discovered by treasure hunters in 2011 near the village of Aliekšycy: 426 denarii and 18 fragments of brooches, which were donated to the Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus. Later, 10 more coins were transferred there. In total, 446 coins are known from the hoard (Vespasian-Septimius Severus).
disposition: Coin Room of the Belarusian State University (10 coins); Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus (436 coins)

summary: 14 Roman bronze coins and one autonomous Histrian coin found in a small ceramic vessel: Hellenistic - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Coin Room, Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: Unknown original number of denarii, 69 preserved: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168); silver weight: 194 g.
A hoard of denarii found at Brixworth, in 1892. It is complete except for one denarius of Antoninus Pius of uncertain reverse. Coins range from Vespasian to Crispina.
Originally, 222 coins. 133 denarii are documented: Nero - Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Iron Gates Museum, Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania (122 coins); inv.no. 562-683; private collection, Bucharest, Romania. (11 coins)

summary: Around 200 denarii. Recovered 135 denarii found with metal vessel: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 141-143).
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 16 denarii found by metal detecting: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-163).
disposition: East Fife Museums, St. Andrews, United Kingdom (5 coins)

summary: 403 denarii: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167-168); bronze and gold jewelry and bronze tweezers.

Galba to Severus. The number of coins in the hoard is estimated and falls somewhere between 1200 and 1500 denarii and 1 drachm of Amisus for Hadrian. Found with a ceramic vessel and few silver ingots.

summary: 15 denarii: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Only 4 sestertii are known: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Unknown number of aurei of the Anoninian house (the number expressed were between 5,000 and 9,000). Only one piece of Antoninus Pius was identified.

summary: 20 denarii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 191).
102 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms found during excavations in the foundation of a house: Claudius I (Messalina) - Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150).

summary: 18 denarii of which two imitations (one hybrid) found as a lump: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). The imitation denarii were struck with the same dies as other two denarii found in Ukraine (Dymowski 2017)

7 denarii: Vespasian 3, Nerva 1, Trajan 1, Marcus aurelius 2 (AD 166-167).
70 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
67 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
During the excavation of the Sanctuary in Insula 20 of Colonia Ulpia Traiana, 6 coins were found deposited under wall plaster. The latest coins date to the period AD 103 to 111.
40 denarii: Titus - Pertinax (AD 193).

A hoard of 86 Roman imperial denarii (from Vespasian to Commodus) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2015 or 2016. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on 10 February 2016 on the treasure hunter forum Violity, but without specifying the exact location of the find. However, on May 25, 2017 on the YouTube channel “Poisk klada Alexander & Co” there was information about the location of the find, as well as photos of the coins previously published on Violity. There is no information about the conditions of the hoard discovery. The coins are of average preservation. In February 2016, the hoard was sold in one lot at Violity auction, the further fate of the coins is unknown.
At least 9 denarii and 1 aureus: Trajan-Hadrian (AD 117-138).
A hoard of five bronze coins (Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia, Topirus), found in grave T2 in Lithochori.
The hoard comprised 17 silver coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) and 43 bronze coins.
35 sestertii, 707.80 g, found on a field ranging from Vespasian/Titus to Commodus (AD 186).
The hoard comprised 31 bronze coins from Augustus to Marcus Aurelius, not further described.
23 denarii: Republic (L. Thorius Balbus) - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

Date of discovery is date of publication, so might be one year earlier. Uncertain number of bronze Tiberius and Marcus Aurelius coins, thus at least 2, found during dike reconstruction found together with glass, bronze objects, terra sigillata, jars, urns and rough earthenware. A bronze purse in the shape of a boat was found in or around 1939 in the same village and might be connected
15 denarii: M. Antony - M. Aurelius (AD 161-180). Only 7 denarii are kept in the coin room of the National Museum of Slovenia in Ljubljana.
disposition: Narodni muzej Ljubljana, Slovenia, 7 coins; dispersed

summary: Hoard of sestertii found while dredging the harbor: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).

322 denarii: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 181-182). The hoard also includes silver and gold jewelry. Gold: 1 bracelet, 1 ring. Silver: 1 patera, 1 chain, 2 brooches, 1 necklace, 1 bracelet, 2 cups. All items were placed in a silver casket.
Around 50 bronze coins were found in a money-box. Only 13 coins were recovered: 5 sestertii, 6 dupondii, 2 asses: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) are kept in the National Museum in Ljubljana.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia (13 coins), inv.no.: 4584-4591; dispersed

summary: Around 200 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Germany (2 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii. 5 coins are kept in the History Museum in Bacău: Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 2, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) 1.
4 sestertii: 2 Marcus Aurelius, 2 Lucilla. Identification based on a picture. (Lang 2007, 257, fig. 153); weight, c. 80 g.

The hoard originally comprised 1,305 Greek/Roman imperial/Roman provincial silver and bronze coins together with gold and silver ancient jewellery. Nowadays 1043 bronze coins and two couple gold earrings are kept in the Archaeological Museum of Shahat. According to the 1934 find report, the missing silver part featured 32 Greek silver coins (280-50 BC, including 16 coins from the Achaean League and four Rhodian drachms), 39 Roman imperial denarii and quinarii (Otho-Trajan, AD 69-116, mint of Rome) and 45 Roman provincial drachms and hemidrachms struck under Trajan (RPC III, 1-3, AD 100). These, as well as 89 sestertii, 77 dupondii, and 128 asses, were probably made in Rome for circulation in Cyrenaica.
Around 150 denarii and a drachm. Only 43 coins provide information on issuers: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
4,418 tetradrachms of Alexandria and three bronze coin: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus). Three large amphorae, filled with coins, dug out of the cellar of a house.
disposition: Type set of 519 coins in Oxford. 114 in London. 80 billon coins, presented to Glasgow in 1902 by the Egypt Exploration Fund and now among the duplicates, probably belong to this hoard. The rest dispersed. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 13 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 191-192).
2 sestertii of Antoninus Pius
The hoard comprised Roman gold and silver coins: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

During the excavation of the Antonine Wall fort on the Bar Hill, a hoard of 13 denarii (Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius Caesar) was found at the bottom of a well. Most of them were imitations, 10 of them were cast of pure tin. Only two of the coins, of Mark Antony and of Vespasian, were genuine struck denarii of silver. One coin, of Hadrian, seemed to be of some alloy of copper, and the remaining 10 coins were cast, of almost pure tin, with no trace of alloy. Of these tin coins, five, of Trajan, seemed to have come from the same moulds, and three others, also of Trajan, seemed to have come from the same moulds. It has been suggested that these were shams expressly manufactured for devotional purposes (throwing of money into wells from superstitious motives).
1243 silver coins: 1241 denarii, 2 drachmas: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 164)

A small hoard of 15 Roman imperial denarii and one Lycian drachm: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was found in April 2017 in Khmelnytskyi region. Information and general photo of the coins of the hoard were published on April, 29, 2017 on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. By the treasure hunter himself, the hoard was called the “purse of denarii”. The coins have a fairly good preservation (weak wear). In early May 2017, the coins were sold at the auction Violity and their fate is unknown.
A hoard of 24 denarii, found on the Dwoberg in 1795. Of these, 22 (Hadrian - Commodus) were found to be in the Oldenburg state museum.
2 denarii - Antoninus Pius for Diva Faustina I and Marcus Aurelius found together with 4 gold bracteates.
The hoard was found on the West of "Blanche-Fontaine" district. A worker discovered an amphora with 1000 aurei, only 164 are now recorded from Augustus to Hadrian.
9 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
The deposit was found at the major Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary site at comprised three asses from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 164.
Unknown number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only two of them were known: 1 Trajan, 1 Faustina II.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 denarii provided information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184).
disposition: Zasadniczej Szkoły Zawodowej w Krasniku Fabrycznym, Poland (1 coin)

summary: The 16 coins listed here (14 sestertii and two dupondii, ranging from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius) were found in the area of the Dampfziegelei in 1897 and 1898. All coins have the same patina and corrosion, so it could be a hoard. Further particulars about the circumstances of the find are undetermined.

453 denarii from Nero to Commodus (AD 180). The latest coin has the reversed inscription as: TR P V IMP IIII COS II P P. The composition of the hoard is described by D. Tacchella (1896) by of number types not by the number of coins (!). There are 224 types: Nero 1, galba 1, Vitellius 1, Vespasian 21, Titus 4, Domitian 9, Nerva 4, Trajan 13, Hadrian 34, Sabina 2, Antoninus Pius 54, Faustina I 23, Marcus Aurelius 30, Faustina II 12, Lucius Verus 6, Lucilla 5, Commodus 1, Crispina 1.
disposition: Some of the coins entered the National Museum in Sofia in 1895.

summary: A mixed hoard of Syrian tetradrachms, Cypriote tetradrachms / didrachms, and denarii, ranging in date from Nero to Hadrian. One coin of Vespasian is countermarked by Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-180), which is why the closing reign is given here as Marcus Aurelius.
11 denarii found on the same field: Caesar – Vespasian (AD 69-79).
826 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 763 denarii were: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167). The hoard was entirely recovered but not published accurate.
Possible hoard of Roman denarii. Only two coins are known, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.
disposition: History Museum, Riga, Latvia (entered in 1928) (inv. no. 120210/1-2)

summary: 96 coins: 10 silver denarii, 1 quinarius, the other 85 coins are copper asses, dupondii and sestertii, and 1 unknown copper denomination. Other finds include 18 wire fibulae, a fragment of a bracelet and 1 unidentified artefact. Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 138-180).
(?) 3 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).
32 bronze coins found glued to each other: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
513 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 101-102)
disposition: Museum of Art History, Vienna, Austria (1847)

summary: 85 denarii: Nerva - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
317 silver coins: 313 denarii, (2 copies and 2 Lycian drachms) with a ceramic vessel, ten meters from BIRNIE 2001: Nero - to Septimius Severus (AD 195-196).
343 bronze coins: 337 sestertii, 6 dupondii: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 193-196). Weight:8205.03 g.
disposition: Saint-Remi History Museum, Reims, France; inv. nos. B-C

summary: The hoard comprised '27 aurei of Vespasian to Commodus along with some silver denarii.' The gold coins were distributed amongst the family of the landowner. Although 9 of the aurei were given to the Musée de Rouen by M. Esnault, these were later stolen.
disposition: Musée de Rouen, France (9 coins. stolen)

summary: The hoard comprised 35 aurei (Nero-Lucius Verus) and 29 silver coins (Nero-Trajan).
5 coins found scattered near a disturbed grave within a cremation necropolis: Hadrian 1 as, Antoninus Pius 4 sestertii (AD 152-153).
The hoard comprised 22 bronze coins from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

The hoard comprised 2,077 bronze coins along with bronze implements and scrap from a bronze foundry. Mostly quandrantes and semisses but also including Greek provincial, Greek, Republican up to 5th century AD
disposition: Heberden Coin Room, AShmolean Museum, Oxford, Great Britain

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 840 well-preserved sestertii, of which 808 were identified by Auvray. The composition of this hoard varies slightly in lists compiled by Ledru and Cauvin. L'annuaire l'An VIII mentions coins of Septimius Severus and of Caracalla from the same parish. It is possible that these were also a part of the hoard, although they have not been added to the database record.
150 denarii. 145 coins entered the History Museum in Svishtov: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 150); silver weight of c. 275.8-468.2 g.
disposition: History Museum, Svishtov, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1614-1735 (145 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of denaarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 10 coins were recovered. Among issuers: Augustus, Tiberius, Nero, Antoninus Pius, Commodus and other emeperors.
11 denarii found with a cooking pot: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-135)
92 denarii: Vitellius – Commodus (AD 180-183).
The hoard comprised 14 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus and was found placed next to two greyware ceramic vessels.
31 denarii found in a ceramic vessel inside a mound: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
(c. 3 kg, c. 900 coins) 196 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 214 Alexandrian tetradrachms from Claudius I to Hadrian. They were found under a floor surface during the excavation of a Late Roman house.
18 sestertii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).

A Roman coin hoard consisting of 106 denarii (Republic - Commodus) was discovered in 1908 during the renovation of a grinding mill, 2 km south-west of Unterammergau. The hoard was in earthenware jar, that had apparently been placed between rocks. The coins are now lost.
Hoard of 21 sestertii. Among them coins of Domitian, Nerva, Hadrianus and Antoninus Pius (AD 138).

Four denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found at Aitnock fort (an Iron Age fort), situated on the summit of a cliff which rises about 60 feet perpendicularly from the waters of the Rye stream at the south-west angle of Hindog Glen near Dalry in Ayrshire. The coins had been wrapped in some material and were found in a layer of occupation.
112 bronze coins: 111 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 195-196).
Unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. Only 41 denarii are recorded: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Diva) (AD 176).
200 bronze coins: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Hoard of 11 sestertii found adjacent to the large Cadeby hoard.
5 AE (2 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius and 2 unidentified)

9 denarii (Vespasian to Trajan) found among the infill of a trench carrying a conduit to service latrines in Building B, outside the north-western corner of the fort. Wheeler (1927) dated the infill (and therefore the construction of the conduit) by the date of the latest coin, arguing that its fine condition supported a deposition soon after its issue around AD 120. Simpson (1967) agreed that the hoard must have been deposited at about this time, but added that the accompanying pottery indicated the conduit and trench belonged to the later second or third centuries. The hoard, therefore, is likely to have been disturbed and moved from its original place of burial among the soil and other waste material used to fill the trench.

Towards the end of October 1878 three aurei were discovered in Bliesen between the Church of St. Remigius and the Rhine road. These date from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius. The coins are now in the collection of the Munzkabinett im Rheinischen Landesmuseum. A fourth aureus in the possession of this museum has been associated with the Bliesen hoard. It dates to the reign of Vespasian (72/3) and was acquired from the Bliesen area.
The hoard comprised '20 coins of which the most recent was an issue of Marcus Aurelius' The hoard was discovered by peat cutters.

A hoard of at least 595 denarii, ranging from Nerva to Crispina, found in the middle of the 19th century in the fortress of Krani in Cephalonia. The coins were given to the Numismatic Museum by the Phocas-Kosmetatos family (in 1970 and 1972).
(32) 2 denarii: Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
Hoard of an unknown number of Roman imperial bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 5 sestertii produced some information: Augustus 1, Nero 2, Hadrian 1, 1 broken.

33 denarii (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found by a party of schoolchildren among rubble in a chamber of the prehistoric and Roman mine workings beneath the hill fort at Llanymynech Ogof. The coins were fused together before being separated by a local antiquarian. A piece of black pottery picked up on another occasion close to the site of the discovery may possibly indicate that the hoard has been disturbed at some time.
disposition: National Museums Wales, Cardiff (part); Oswestry Museum (part)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Only 20 denarii were documented: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (Crispina (AD 161-180).

A hoard of 298 aurei dating from Nero to Lucius Verus was discovered in Vienna in 1799 during the construction of the Wiener Neustadt Canal. Of the 298 aurei, 24 were stolen and 274 initially were recovered. There is information for 279 coins: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The average weight of the coins was 6.3g.
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (191 coins)

summary: (ca.30) 12 sestertii and dupondii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; auxiliary fund, inv.no. 693

summary: Hoard of 23 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189); silver weight: 52.27 g.
The hoard comprised a mixed hoard of gold, silver, and bronze deposited in relation to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

A Roman burial was discovered in the spring of 1929 in widening the south side of the Ashford-Maidstone-London road. This almost certainly represents an untouched cremated deposit. Together with other objects, it contained 18 gold coins or disks.
