Mr. I.L. Faingold may have inherited a hoard of 100 denarii from his father. 44 coins were documented: Galba - Commodus (AD 190).
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (44 coins until 1917)

summary: Six gold Roman coins found in a burial: Vespasian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 4.
Four denarii (Vespasian - Trajan), allegedly found in 1845 in or around Minden. It is not impossible that these belonged to the Minden I find, made in 1844.
A hoard of ca. 300 denarii, found in 1842, during peat digging, close to the so-called 'Römerbrücke' in the Bourtanger Moor. The coins are now lost, except for two.
Over 60 denarii found on a field during 19th-21st centuries: Vespasian - septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: National Museum of Archaeology, Warszaw, Poland (6 coins); Private collection (21 coins)

summary: 408 denari found by metal detecting: Nero - Hadrian. No further detail.
A find, comprising one aureus and seven denarii, was made at the south end of site XXVIII. The coins were found loose on the floor of a house of the Antonine period.
2 aurei: Nero, Antoninus Pius .
Unknown number of denarii hoard. 4 coins entered museum collection in Yambol: Vespasian 2, Nerva 1, Trajan 1.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2924-2929

summary: Hoard of two aurei - Claudius I, Trajan - and one imitation - Nero/Antoninus Pius.
20 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189). Among them two imitations. Together it was found an iron axe typical for the Chernyakhov culture (4th-5th centuries AD).
Hoard of 800 denarii. Among them, three pieces of Pertinax
Twenty-two denarii found on an agricultural land: Otho - Commodus (AD 187-188).
16 aurei: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 107-110).
37 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No details on the structure.
Unknown originally number of coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among the coins were recognized those of Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).
The hoard originally comprised an undetermined amount of denarii. Only 12 coins are known: Trajan-Marcus Aurelius (114-175 AD).
The hoard comprised approximately 2,000 sestertii of the Antonine period.
Unknown originally number of coins. 78 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 189).
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal

summary: A group of 19 Roman silver coins (of the Emperors Nero, Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, and the Empress Faustina), found while ploughing at Pitcullo in Fife, presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1781. The 19 coins have not been located in NMAS, Edinburgh
The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing 50 corroded, worn, illegible Roman coins, with the exception being two sestertii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.

find_spot_name: VILLA DE LA FUENTE DE LAS PULGUINAS
summary: Five bronze coins found one next to the other: as Republic, 3 asses Hadrian, 1 dupondius Antoninus Pius.

The coins were found in a block, stuck together with corrosion products and comprised 151 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Commodus. The coins were found during gravel extraction in the river and may represent a hoard washed out from a riverbank or a votive deposit.

Several hundreds coins (principally of Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, and Faustina), found in 1842, while removing some sods from the surface of a piece of moss land. Three publications (see under references) list groups of coins belonging to this hoard. Some coins had marks indicating that the hoard had been buried in a bag of coarse cloth. One further denarius of Trajan in HCC, p. 34, no. 207, Glasgow.
70 denarii: 69 Rome issues, 1 imitation: Trajan - Commodus (AD 187-188). Together, it was found a ring made of a silver-coloured metal.

Found in the garden of one of the villagers. Consisted of denarii (quantity unknown), which were in a pot. The coins were taken by villagers. V. Lyaskoronsky in 1926 saw only two denarii from this hoard (Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius). In 1964, L. Pobal examined the probable place of the find, but did not find additional information about the hoard.
19 asses found within one square meters: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 177).
A hoard of 5 denarii (Vitellius - Lucilla), found while digging peat not far from Nauen. A connection with the hoard of BUCHOW-KARPZOW (ID 17335) has been postulated.
The hoard comprised 15 copper-alloy coins from Hadrian to Commodus and we found next to a skeleton.
52 aurei ranging from Nero (AD 63/66) to Marcus Aurelius (AD 164), found at the Stephansgasse, in the foundations of a stone building. This hoard could be connected with the Marcomannic wars.
(150) 109 coins: 18 denarii, 19 antoniniani, 2 sestertii, 70 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 42.3-83.4 g.
disposition: History Museum, Kazanlak, Bulgaria (20 coins); Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1566-1672 (106 coins)

summary: Circa 13,000 antoniniani (radiates) found in two ceramic vessels. Among issuers: Gallienus, Postumus, Tetricus I; silver weight: c.3508.5-16237.8g.

Over 4,500 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 293 -294) found in a room (same rooms as KOM AUSHIM A51, A100, A115, A118, A119), stored on the floor, during excavations of a house.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 3,000 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I described as being small in size and therefore likely to be barbarous.
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 74 denarii (232g) were analysed by the Archaeological Commission: Vespasian Septimius Severus. Four coins were described in detail.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg (1891), Russia; Podillya Antiquities Museum, Kamyanets-Podilsky, Ukraine (4 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 300 'small bronze' Roman coins, probably radiates. Only one coin was described, a radiate of Probus with a MARS VICTOR reverse.
42 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 12 have been examined: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised approximately 11 kilos of third century antoniniani (radiates). Only 330 coins are known by issuers: Valerian I and Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270).
43,433 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 274-275); silver weight: 11726.9-54290.3 g
(247) 162 silver coins: 65 denarii, 97 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 266-267).
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (161 coins, 1 fragment of container)

summary: 5 kg of silver coins with issuers from Nero to Severus Alexander. Only 1,350 were recovered, among which: 233 Septimius Severus, 71 Caracalla, 5 Elagabalus, 5 Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); Silver weight: 1764.3-3938.9 g.
The hoard comprised about 4,000 coins of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius II, Aurelian and Probus in a vessel. There may be two hoards.
The hoard comprised 32 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

A hoard of 543 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus), antoniniani (Gordian III - Gallienus) and one bronze coin (Gordian III) found at Dura Europos, in a house near the city wall which had been buried in the great embankment with which the walls themselves were reinforced.
698 silver coins: 1 denarius, 697 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 268); silver weight: 190.0-1811.7 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (10 coins of Postumus); collection De Bove (34 coins), in 1882

summary: During the drainage of a moor several small Roman coins were unearthed. The names of six emperors are mentioned. Some coins seem to be plated.

25 antoniniani (hoard or purse) bought in 1938 from a drunken labouring man who claimed to have found them in the Dünnern river bed. Coins range from Aurelian to Carinus: 15 Aurelian, 9 Probus, 1 Carinus. 22 coins out of the 25 are clearly identified/preserved today (15 Aurelian and 7 Probus).
(116) 101 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 241).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CXXIV

summary: The hoard comprised 110 Roman bronze coins from Augustus to Gordian III with a tpq of AD 239.
(200) 162 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: c.251.5-548.5 g. Found together with two bronze bracelets.

Approximately 10,000 coins. Information on only 925 pieces, billon Alexandrian. Portion of a hoard in the possession of Louis T. Dilauro, June, 1979. Some 400 additional pieces were said to have been culled at random, and the original size of the whole is said to have been in the range of 10000 pieces.
disposition: Louis T. Dilauro (June, 1979, part of the hoard); 3 in New York, the rest in trade. Detailed list in New York (William E. Metcalf).

summary: A hoard of 1,016 of coins was found with an amphora. The majority of coins were bronze issues of the Bosporus kingdom. A billon antoninianus (radiate) of Gordian III was found among the coins.
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Simferopol

summary: A hoard of 11 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella, Dium, the koinon of Macedonia) ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Gordian III, found in a grave, part of a vast necropolis in the eastern part of Veroia.
134 silver coins: 6 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259-260); silver weight: 166.1-340.8 g.
248 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 14

summary: 27 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised two vessels containing 3,080 coins. Cousin mentions 3,074 coins, but the list of reverses that he gives has a total of 3,071 and the total by emperor is 3,084. He also described reverse types but does not match them with their obverses. The last coins are 115 SAECVLI FELICITAS issues of Postumus (Elmer 593). It was found within 7 or 8 metres of Hoard ÉTAPLES 1840 1 during archaeological excavations directed by L. Cousin.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 105 pieces entered the museum collection in Popovo and Targovishte: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Popovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 306 (92 coins); History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 689 (13 coins)

summary: (+2000) 1478 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 361.1-2499.1 g+
The hoard comprised 1,500 Roman coins from Vespasian to Philip I (AD 244-249).

462 coins, mostly provincial issues of Caesarea in Cappadocia (150 coins) and imperial bronzes (130 coins), other bronze provincial issues and some imperial silver, closing with Gordian III, found in a deposit associated with the mid-third-century destruction of Zeugma.
2,648 antoniniani (radiates) in a lump of over 5 kg: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt; Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (16 coins)

summary: A hoard found in 1865 under a mound of quarry stone in the middle of the locality. It comprised perhaps 800 denarii, dating from Trajan to Maximinus I. 765 (the catalogue is numbered to 766, but no. 677 is omitted) of these are recored in in detail by FMRD. The coins were in a pot, next to which a bracelet and a fibula were also found.
361 antoniniani/radiate: Gallienus - Tetrachy (AD 292-293)

A mixed hoard of denarii, some sestertii and a few antoniniani, ranging from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. It was found in soil dug out during building work in Niederlahnstein (Weiherstraße). The hoard, which was partly dispersed, might have comprised 200 coins or more, but a description of only 142 exists.
500 sestertii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Severus alexander (AD 226).
The hoard comprised approximately 300 radiates of which 64 survive.

In 1958 a small collective find of 18 antoniniani ranging from Aurelian to Carinus Caesar was unearthed in a ditch during excavations conducted by the commission for archaeological exploration of late antique Raetia.
287 Roman imperial bronze coins (sestertii and antoniniani (radiates) found under a slab: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
(?) 51 sestertii: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231).
A hoard of six provincial coins minted in Alexandria (Claudius II - Aurelian), found in or near Ipswich in 1922.
32 antoniniani ranging from Gordian III to Aemilian.
Hoard of 32 coins found with ceramic vessel: 21 denarii, 11 sestertii: Trajan - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).
73 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv. nos.1538-1610 (73 coins, 69 have been stolen)

summary: 4,116 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 2 bronzes: Greek - Diocletian/Maximian (AD 284-295). Acquired in Egypt by Dattari.
disposition: 185 were sent to Macalister. The rest is partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford (Milne)

summary: 475 silver coins: 1 Celtic drahm, 1 provincial drachm, 3 republican denarii, 470 imperial, found in the river near the former Postumius Bridge pillar. It was presumed that the coins may have been kept in a chest/box: Celtic - Gordian III (AD 240).
disposition: Musei Civici di Castelvecchio di Verona, Italy

summary: The hoard comprised numerous fragments of silvered copper-alloy tableware accompanied by 21 sestertii and antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Philip I (AD 244-249). TAF interprets it as a deposit of scrap metal intending for recycling.

The hoard comprised 214 denarii and radiates from Commodus to Gordian III which are today lost. Also found in the excavations as isolated finds were a denarius of Septimius Severus, and 2 bronzes of Severus Alexander. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 313.3-487.1g

407 silver coins found in two glass bottles. One bottle contained 130 coins, the other 277 pieces: 86 denarii, 321 antoniniani (radiates): Domitian - Victorinus (AD 269-271). In one of the bottles were also found a pendant medallion (with a denarius of Antoninus Pius) and a silver finger ring.
disposition: Service Régional de l’Archéologie, Ile-de- Franceté; Centre Michel de Boüard – Centre de recherches archéologiques et historiques anciennes et médiévales, Caen

summary: 483 antoniniani: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282)
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (unknown number)

summary: Eight coins found inside a sarcophagus: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The find consists of 10 late Roman bronze coins (Tetricus, and other Gallic emperors), found in the area of the 'Kulturhaus am Hexenturm'
The hoard comprised approximately 500 Roman billon coins (radiates), with the most recent being issues of Diocletian and Maximian.
A hoard of three coins (similar to the coins of hoard Kassanreia 2008A) was found in a destruction layer in Room Θ, of the same large urban Roman building.
The hoard comprised 3,604 small module radiate copies, known as 'minimi' [antoniniani (radiates)]. The hoard was found in an amphora covered by a tile while digging foundations for a building
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliotheque Natiobnale de France (in 1937)

summary: Originally there appear to have been 19 antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, However, Mattingly only reported on 18.
Over 1,500 coins were discovered at the Roman villa. Only 790 antoniniani (radiates) were studied: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
(+1000) 92 antoniniani: Gordian - Valerian I (AD 253-259
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (63 coins); dispersed -1981

summary: A hoard of 120+ Syrian tetradrachms dating from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus.
Four coins (two denarii and two antoniniani, Septimius Severus - Gallienus), apparently found together around 1845 on a field between Stegelitz and Fehlitz.
47 silver coins: 4 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Caracalla-Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 70.4-108.5 g.
58 antoniniani, ranging from Caracalla to Volusian.

Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 4 coins provided some data: 2 denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius, Elagabalus, Maximinus I Thrax, Gallienus (sole reign).
The hoard comprised 438 (or only 380) sestertii found in a black coarse ceramic vessel: Augustus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The find of Adlerterrain in 1903 comprised twelve antoniniani and denarii ranging from Maximinus Thrax to Gallienus.
50 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Claudius II (Divus) (AD 270).
"Few hundreds" Roman coins found in a field. Only 33 coins provided some information and some of them have been entered to the level of the coin. The precision is not certain.
The hoard includes 6 denari and 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Philip I (AD 103-247) kept in a private collection.
127 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Carus (AD 282-283) found on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 102 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in Cairo

summary: 676 Roman imperial bronzes found in the ground: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
The hoard comprised 7.5 kg of antoniniani (radiates)of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Aurelian, Severina, Tacitus and Probus. 2,000 coins are identified.

The hoard comprised one vessel containing a harness fitting and 800 copper-alloy and silver coins of Commodus, Pertinax, Septimius Severus, Albinus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Plautilla, Geta, Macrinus, Elagabalus, Julia Paula, Julia Maesa, Julia Soaemias, Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Orbiana, Gordian I, Pulpienus, Balbinus, Gordianus III, Philip I, Philip II, Otacilia Severa and Herennius Etruscus.
1007 silver coins: 201 denarii, 806 antoniniani: Trajan - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268). Together with a silver brooch.

11 antoniniani (radiates) found with a small ceramic vessel in a well: Gordian III - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). The hoard was found together with a brooch and/or a Gold ring (according to Dembski).
The hoard comprised 5,200, 1 denarius and antoniniani (radiates) found with ceramiv vessel: Maximinus I Tharx -Diocletian and Maximian I (before AD 294).

A ceramic vessel with 1,032 Roman provincial bronze coins minted in Marcianopolis, Nicopolis ad Istrum, Callatis, Odessus, Anchialus, Augusta Traiana, Hadrianopolis, Philippopolis and Creteia-Flaviopolis: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 201 (894 coins)

summary: Circa 780 broze coins, 778 studied: 776 imperial bronzes, 1 dupondius/as, 1 provincial coin (koinon of Cyprus): Vespasian to Philip I.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale, Paris, France

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 20 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 825-844 (20 coins)

summary: 17 sestertii and middle bronzes from Augustus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised two small urns containing more than 1,000 poorly preserved radiates from Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus (AD 276-282).

The hoard comprised a broken vessel containing more than 850 radiates (the total is estimated at approximately 1,000 coins). The hoard was buried in a cemetery, not far from the village. The hoard was discovered by chance.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 sestertii from Hadrian to Septimius Severus.
The hoard comprised a small number of antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus. 16 of the coins were catalogued.
Hoard of 100 coins of Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalkes, Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.

The hoard comprised an enormous pot containing a very large quantity of Gallo-Roman coins. Although some of the coins were stolen soon after their discovery, the number of coins found totaled more than 2,000. Only 85 of these were described. After its discovery, the pot was left in the middle of the field overnight and some coins from the hoard went missing then: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 541.0-2499.1g.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 151 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 41.7-187.8 g.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (inv.no. 327, 2 coins)

summary: 698 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

The hoard comprised a bronze vessel containing 821 antoniniani (radiates). The catalogue made by Blanchet is not accurate. Aubin published a lot of 21 radiates in 1981 which probably came from the hoard. However, it is not clear whether these are additions or whether they were included in the original numbers. The hoard was found by a farmer. Silver: 821 coins; Silver weight: 222.6-1025.3 g.
disposition: Musée d'Archéologie Nationale, Saint-Germain-en-Laye, France (copper-alloy vessel, inv.no. 50253)

summary: A hoard of 15,000 - 20,000 coins, found ploughing a field at Riby Wold Farm on the east side of Lincolnshire Wolds, some 4-5 miles north-east of Caistor. The coins are all antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Probus, AD 281. Included were many coins of Gallienus, and of emperors from the Gallic Empire.
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part: pot and 24 coins); Ashmoleum Museum (part)

summary: 62 coins: 1 aureus, 56 denarii and 5 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-256).
6 antoniniani (radiates) found in a small ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) 2, Claudius II 2 Probus 2.

of 4,033 pieces, 3296 were recorded at the British Museum: 592 denarii, Domitian-Gordian III; 2704 antoniniani, Caracalla-Trajan Decius, including 2 “Divi”. The other were all antoniniani of Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II and Trajan Decius.
874 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO B)
summary: Hoard in grave, 13 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270-275).
Originally were 420 silver coins. 274 pieces were recovered: 1 denarius, 273 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Gallienus/Postumus (AD 259-268).
disposition: Town Museum Koprivnica, Croatia (274 coins); partly dispersed - 1982

summary: 17 coins: 1 denarius, 16 provincial bronzes: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2491

summary: The hoard comprised a glass cup -'coupe de verre' - containing 20 antoniniani (radiates) of Postumus and Tetricus I.
The hoard comprised 76 double sestertii, sestertii and asses from Domitian to Postumus (AD 260-268).

The hoard was found in a well in a Gallo-Roman villa and comprised two vessels containing a little more than 900 radiates of Elagabalus, Philip, Herennia Etruscilla and Postumus. More than 600 pieces were issues of Postumus.

Large numbers of moulds for casting spurious coins, principally antoniniani of the period AD 260-74, have been found at Lyons Court Farm, Whitchurch, near Bristol, in 1891, 1897 and 1960. Coins were found as well, clearly part of a hoard accidentally incorporated into the levelling-material. In 1891, 16 Roman bronze coins were found while cleaning a ditch: Faustina 2, Lucilla 2, Commodus 10, Crispina 1, Postumus 1, associated with large stones, animal bones, and sherds of Samian, Upchurch and rougher pottery. Followed the discovery of a bronze of Commodus, and one of Maximinus. In 1897, additional clay moulds were found and 2 bronze coins oxidised together (Commodus, Septimius Severus). The 1960 finds include a sestertius of Marcus Aurelius and 4 antoniniani (3 Tetricus II and 1 Aurelian).
1040 (996) antoniniani (radiates): Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274); silver weight: 281.8-1299.1g.
The hoard comprised 283 tetradrachms dated between the reigns of Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) and Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
34 sestertii: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised more than 212 sestertii and antoniniani (radiates) from Hadrian to Postumus. All the coins with clear reverses of Postumus were from his 1st issue at Trier, suggesting a tpq of AD 260 to 261. However, 16 of the coins of Postumus were described as having 'diverse' reverses so we cannot be exactly certain of this date.
Unknown initial number of provincial bronze coins. 50 coins are kept in the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 22 092-22 141 (50 coins)

summary: The hoard was found near Keldenich, on the Tanzberg in an earthenware urn that was shattered by the workers who found it. It comprised 10 pound (or 20?) of Roman silver coins. The coins (4000 according to Haupt) were dispersed and only the names of some of the emperors represented were recorded (Vespasian - Severus Alexander).

The assemblage comprised 20 'small bronzes' (Tacitus and Probus) assumed to be antoniniani (radiates) dating to the end of the third century AD. Blanchet considered the find to be a small hoard. TAF suggests it might be a purse hoard. The hoard was found during demolition of an old building.
67 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); silver weight: 95.2-182.9 g.
201 sestertii from Domitian to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254-255).
1 kilo of antoniniani (radiates). Among the coins, 20 were issues of Claudius II (AD 268-270).
128 silver coins (antoniniani?): Balbinus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

The hoard comprised 24 coins which were scattered over an area measuring approximately 1m² , a fragment of a copper-alloy brooch dating to the second half of the first century AD and a piece of copper-alloy. They were found at the site of a Gallo-Roman villa where in 1919 another hoard of coins was found. It is possible that they are part of the same deposit.
A hoard of 8 Roman Provincial coins from the mints of Thessalonica, Edessa, Pella and the Macedonian Koinon from the period AD 222-235, found in grave 52 in the western cemetery of Pella.

A hunter stooping to pick up a hare, noticed 30 Roman coins scattered on the ground surface. Further investigation led to the discovery of another 50 coins, presumably a hoard dispersed by ploughing: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised Roman coins dating to the third century AD.

149 Roman provincial silver and bronze coins found with a bag during archaeological excavations: 10 silver coins (4 didrachms, 6 drachms) of Caesarea in Cappadocia, ranging from Hadrian to Septimius Severus; 139 bronze provincial coins of Trapezus, ranging from Commodus (?, or Septimius Severus?) to Philip I (certainly AD 244/5, as this is the last time Trapezus produces coins). Authors disagree on the identification of the coins of Trapezus. These are badly preserved and were never published in detail. The list given here follows Kropotkin, as given in Depeyrot's translation. Golenko has a slightly different breakdown, including the mention of 4 coins of Clodius Albinus, allegedly from Trapezus. Kapanadze and Golenko also list 7 coins of Commodus, though these were grouped with Septimius Severus as uncertain by Kropotkin. The list provided in Tsotelia / Depeyrot 2010 does not offer further clarifications.
116 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). The issues are from the mints from Moesia and Thracia, mainly Marcianopolis, Nicopolis ad Istrum and Viminacium
Hoard of 17 silver coins, comprising 7 denarii (Elagabal to Maximinus) and 10 radiates (Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus)
21 coins discovered within the ruins of a Roman settlement. 11 pieces in the museum of Targovishte: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard was found in a funerary urn and apparently comprised 50 'small bronzes' or radiates of Gallienus.
A depot of 8 antoniniani and 1 denarius (Septimius Severus - Claudius II) found in a pit on one of the rooms of the villa rustica at Oensingen
500 antoniniani (radiates): Probus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).

50 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II were found in association with the jaw bone of a skeleton in a lead coffin, suggesting that they had been placed inside the mouth of the corpse. The coins were characterised be being excessively thin and were therefore thought to be minimi.
Around 200 denarii. 7 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235) are known..
It comprised 187 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Nerva - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
21 denarii and 28 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

These coins were found during the excavation of an imperial building. They appear to represent the remains of two separate hoards. The first (A) may have been deposited in the middle of the third century AD (AD 249). The second (B) composed of radiates dates to AD 270 to 275.
449 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised more than 230 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta and Julia Domna) - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 288.1-596.9 g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (198 coins; inv.nos. III 2099-2102); Musée d'Avranches (32 coins)

summary: During the excavations of 1890, a hoard of 170 bronze coins were discovered: 169 sestertii and 1 provincial bronze: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-268).
105 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 31173-31277

summary: 5 coins found in room 3 of the House of Four Season: Commodus 1 denarius, Septimius Severus 1 denarius, Caracalla 1 denarius, Julia Mamaea 1 sestertius, Maximinus I Trax 1 sestertius.

Unknown initial number of silver coins. 6 coins are known in the collection of the Salzburger Museum Carolino Augusteum: Septimius Severus 2, Julia Domna 1, Caracalla 1, Maximinus I Thrax 1, Gordian III 1.
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins, 5 of which have been identified.
The hoard comprised 'approximately 120 Roman bronzes, principally sestertii, of which many were very crudely manufactured 'trés frustes'.
The hoard comprised 9 antoniniani (radiates). The emperors represented include Gordian, Trebonianus Gallus, Valerian I, Gallienus and Salonina. There is no catalogue.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain

summary: 28 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I (AD 258-259); silver weight: 35.0g.
17 antoniniani (radiates). According to Boersma 1967, no. 175, they are dated between AD 253-268. No further information.
49 coins: 3 silver and 46 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2100-2148 (49 coins)

summary: The hoard derives from the collection of the musician Simon Antoni, which was acquired by the Kreuznach museum in 1888, with an inventory of 1488 Roman coins. Of these, some coins were found 'am Lemberg', probably between 1830 and 1860. FMRD lists 102 antoniniani, ranging from Valerian (for Saloninus) to Tetricus.
869 antoniniani (radiates), barbarous imitations: Divus Claudius II and Tetrici (AD 271-274).
disposition: Thermenmuseum Heerlen; Koninklijk Penningkabinet, The Hague, Netherlands

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 31 pieces are kept in the Regional History Museum in Vratsa: Septimius Severus - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M VI 9663-9693 (31 coins)

summary: 11 antoniniani: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

The hoard comprised 10.6kg of coins. Mints represented are Rome (3195); Milan (135); Viminiacium (1); Siscia (151), Sirmium (2), Antioch (1); Cyzicus (10); Cologne (13); Trier (11); uncertain (53) Found during the construction of a vault. Silver: 28, 3590, 47 coins; Silver weight: 1008.5-4527.4
The hoard was found inside a textile bag placed within a ceramic vessel and comprised approximately 300 silver coins, apparently all antoniniani (radiates). The hoard has a tpq of AD 261.
Over 2,891 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian (AD 287-288) found in an amphora beneath the floor, during excavations of a house.
2,634 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Carus (AD 283).
2,000 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Dispersend among locals, and buyers from Novara and Torino.

summary: A hoard of circa 169 provincial coins of Tarsus found on the site of the ancient city ranging in date from Septimius Severus to Trebonianus Gallus.

The hoard comprised 1,094 antoniniani (radiates) including issues of Valerian I, Gallienus, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Claudius II, Divus Claudius II, Quintillus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II and Aurelian. Silver weight: 208.4-798.1 g.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 600 coins. They are described as being base silver coins from Caracalla to Gordian III. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 751.3g and 1558.7g

74 (FMRO VI/1), around 60 bronze coins (Dembski 1977) were found in a Roman well. No certainty whether these coins belonged to a hoard or they were single finds as votive offerings. The coins minted segment: Tiberius - Numerian.
745 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 293).
The hoard comprised over 1,000 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel. 640 coins have been seen: Titus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

IARCH record for scattered hoard of radiates (for full details see DOR-5D3543). Another hoard was previously found on the same field in 2013 (2013 T221 'Holt') with an addenda found in 2014 (2014 T962).
Few hundreds coins found with a large ceramic vessel and wonderful jewelry. 53 coins were studied: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 239-241); silver weight: 75.8-153.3 g.
disposition: Museum of Oltenia, Craiova, Romania (53 coins).

summary: The hoard was found in the foundations of a 15th century house and comprised a small deposit of 3rd century coins. J. Chappée told Blanchet there were 10 coins: Victorinus 2, Tetricus I 3, Tetricus II 5.
2 coins: 1 bronze Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/ Diva Faustina II), 1 antoninianus (radiate) Claudius II (AD 268-270)
247 antoniniani (radiates): Gordiasn III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
The hoard comprised 33 radiates of which 25 are Divus Claudius II radiates (AD 270).
The hoard comprised 16 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Caracalla and Elagabalus.

Found during construction work. The subsequent excavations provided no information on any archaeological context. The findspot is situated in the slope above the vicus of Muralto. Hoard/deposition of 4869 aes coins: 1 as, 1 dupondius and 4867 sestertii, in an amphora, Claudius I to Gallienus (253/254).
The hoard was found in two vessels by workers. For the city master, it comprised c. 8,000 antoniniani (radiates). Among these coins, 796 from Valerian to Diocletian were identified.
160 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Sold to a British private collector.

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 55 silver coins: 10 denarii, 45 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius; silver weight: 15.3-26.2 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum of Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv. nos. M V 8541-8596

summary: 642 BI radiates to AD 282. Addenda of 100 coins found in 2015.

The hoard comprised 'a large quantity of 3rd century coins, of which 39 were given by M. Richard to the Musée de Laval (Mayenne): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 12.5-46.8g. Three coins, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I Thrax and Saloninus are lost.
42 bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Caracalla (AD 215).
disposition: Collection J. De Bast (42 coins), in 1808

summary: 84 sestertii and 1 forgery: Trajan - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
575 denarii: Nero – Gordian III (AD 238-244).

The hoard comprised 773 aurei - 18 coins were already missing in 1874 - from Claudius I to Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) with a tpq of AD 205-207 and was found in association with a staircase, presumably part of a Roman building or cellar. There are at least 3 different catalogues giving different totals of coins and it is likely that on discovery several coins were retained by the workmen who discovered the find. The Cabinet des Médailles acquired 15 coins from the hoard, for which RIC level data is available. Hobbs estimates a gold weight of approximately 8520.6 to 9239.4g.
5 denarii found with a bronze item in a well: Trajan/Hadrian - Caracalla/Elagabalus. (201-222).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing '30 silver and bronze coins, including 1 of Nero. It is possible that this hoard is the same as the hoard of large and medium bronzes of Domitian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus and Gordian III which were examined by Deville.
The hoard was found in an iron cooking pot or 'marmite' and comprised an uncertain number of silver coins and some jewellery, such as 'large finger rings'.

The hoard comprised 67 Provincial coins mostly from local mints (Thessalonica, Macedonian Koinon) of the time of Gordian III, found in a Roman farmhouse located in a field southeast of the provincial road, west of Afytos.

The hoard was found in 1989 in a field near Chalfont St Peter. The coins were contained in four pots, of which pots I, II and III were buried close together, and pot IV at a distance of four metres. The total number of coins in the hoard was 6,682: 15 bronze coins, 45 denarii, 2511 antoniniani of the Central Empire, 3560 antoniniani of the Gallic Empire, 197 irregular coins, and 354 uncertain coins.
disposition: British Museum (part); Bucks. County Museum, Aylesbury (part)

summary: The hoard comprised 19 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 255-257 and AD 271-272.
Five radiates "of Tetricus" found near the surface by a digger driver during gravel extraction at the site of the now destroyed supposed Iron Age hillfort known as "The Walls" in Nursling.

The total number of coins found is estimated at approximately 5,000, of which only a small proportion were identified as issues of a particular emperor. The emperors represented were: Gallienus, Claudius II, Severina, Quintillus and Aurelian. The coins were of base silver and were therefore sold.
90 silver coins: 23 denarii, 67 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 125.5-252.4 g.
444 silver coins found with a bronze vessel: Domitian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Together were found two silver spoons

The hoard contained approximately 450 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of Vespasian, Antoninus Pius (?),Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, Julia Paula, Severus Alexander, Balbinus, Gordian III, Philip I, Otacilia Severa, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Postumus. The most abundant were coins of Gordian, Philip I, Gallienus and Postumus. The attribution of coinage to Antoninus Pius is doubtful as the coin described belongs to Caracalla (RIC 277c).

The hoard comprised 39 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus. They were found under a layer of burnt material and many of the coins were blackened, melted or twisted. 34 coins were minted in Rome, 3 in Viminacium and 1 in Cologne with the latest coin being a Cologne issue from AD 256 to 258. Although TAF notes the mint distribution, they are not assigned to coins of particular emperors.
Originally, 87 silver coins. 66 pieces were recovered: 18 antoniniani (radiates), 48 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Collection Nussbaum, Timișoara, Romania; otherwise, dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised close to 1,800 antoniniani (radiates), mostly of Postumus.
12 bronze coins of Viminacium probably issued under Gordian III and Philip I (AD 246-247)
disposition: Museum of Sofia; inv. nos. CIII and CLXVII (1936 and 1953)

summary: Unknown number of antoniniani. Dr. Harlanov examined 15 pieces: Caracalla 1, Gordian III 13, Philip I 1; silver weight: 20.1-37.6 g.

7,000 coins were found in a pot, consisting of only three types (2 of Tetricus, 1 of Claudius II Gothicus). At the time, they believed that they were set aside to serve as Charon's obol for fallen soldiers.
8 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: History Museum, Lovech, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1482 (8 coins)

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 10 pieces entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N 0056 /1-10/

summary: Around 700 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. For only two coins are known the issuers: Domitian and Septimius Severus. The archives mention that the coins were minted between years 81 and 222.
The hoard comprised between 400 and 500 sestertii from Trajan to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238). 92 were acquired by the City Museum of Nevers.
(5 or 6 kg. coins, c.1500 coins?) silver coins, 16 recovered: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 21.5-34.9 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2499; 16 coins

summary: A farmer from Unter-Horgen found a hoard while fertilizing a marshy pasture. During this work he saw a number of coins laying next to a vessel in a ditch. The hoard comprised possibly up to 600 coins. The list given in FMRD encompasses 274 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Antoninus Pius to Marius.

Remains of a wealthy residential development was unearthed during excavation for the new synagogue. In the process 11 Roman bronze coins were found (2 großerz of Antoninus Pius, 2 mittelerz of Commodus, and klenerz from the father Tetricus).
The hoard was found in a stone conduit at a mineral water source and comprised 67 Roman bronze and billon coins from Claudius I to Tetricus I.
Unknown initial number of coins. 29 provincial bronze coins are known: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
758 imperial and provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 42288-46046

summary: The hoard was found during the course of a rescue excavation and comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian and Gallienus.
Unknown number of silver coins. 29 coins entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
25 silver coins: 2 denarius, 23 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

The 9 coins (5 denarii, 3 bronzes and 1 antoninianus, to Severus Alexander) was found in 1780 with other relics, in a meadow near Marbach, at the confluence of Neckar and Murr. It is labelled as 'Kollektivfund' in FMRD, not as hoard.

The hoard comprised 64 barbarous radiates of Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I and 26 unstruck flans. They were found during the excavation of a cave, not far from Berdorf. The presence of several identical coins and unstruck flans suggests that there was a forger's mint somewhere in the vicinity.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg (84 coins); private collection (5 coins)

summary: The original total number of coins in the hoard is not known, although 14 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 31 radiates of the third century AD. Chardome examined 18 in the Musèe de Beaufort in August 1973. Collin and Provost provide a different catalogue of 7 Gallienus, 5 Claudius II, 3 Postumus, 4 Victorinus, 1 Tetricus I, I Tetricus II.
disposition: Musèe de Beaufort, France (18 coins studied)

summary: The hoard comprised 60 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and Tetricus II.
Six aurei of Gallienus (sole) coins found during the development works of the harbor. Very doubtful.
(30) 7 silver and bronze coins: 2 denarii, 1 antoniniani; 1 provincial bronze; 3 bronze unid. denom: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Private collection Andrei Pănoiu - architect, Bucharest, Romania

summary: An amphora with 2 antoniniani and 7 nummi ranging from Tacitus to the first Tetrarchy found on the seabed.
65 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257); silver weight: 82.6-167.6 g.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1,759 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Victorinus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 404.6g.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1,968 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). 1,862 of these coins were identifiable (219 denarii and 1,643 antoniniani (radiates) and form the basis of a catalogue by Le Gentilhomme (1946). The current hoard catalogue outlined here needs checking against this original publication.
The hoard comprised 1 denarius of Elagabalus and 15 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 7.3 to 19.6 g.
The hoard comprised 120 sestertii from Vespasian to Philip I (AD 244-249).

A hoard of 381 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani ranging from Geta to Postumus) and 1 provincial coin, found in a vessel surrounded by fire rubble in a building located in front of the SE corner of the Roman fort. The coins had been contained in a bag made of hemp. A large number of ornaments had been placed on top to the vessel.
The hoard comprised an iron vessel containing between 700 and 800 coins of Elagabalus to Postumus (AD 260-269).
Three Roman hoards found in Stonea. This hoard comprises 22 denarii ranging up to Severus Alexander.
230 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

51 radiates (Volusian to Victorinus) found in the course of excavations at the Cambria House site on the civil settlement outside the legionary fortress at the NW corner. The coins were in the filling of a drain, but it is not clear whether they represent a deliberate deposit or an accidental loss.
The hoard comprised 94 provincial bronze coins dated between AD 49/50 and 252/3.
The hoard comprised approximately 50 silver coins (almost certainly radiates) from Gordian III to Gallienus.
147 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269).

Mints: Rome (332); Nicomedia (11: Elagabalus); Antioch (6: 1 Caracalla and 5 Gordian III); 3 copies of Gordian III. Silver: 139, 213 coins; Silver weight: 462.0-912.5g The hoard was found during levelling works at a sawmill.

Around circa 1,000 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Claudius II (AD 268-270) and some Gallic usurpers. Coins were split between the finder, the field owner, and the local museum.

A hoard of 30 coins (2 uncertain, 1 Imperial Roman; 27 provincial coins: Dion, Odessa, Pella, Koinon of Macedonia, Thessalonica, Cassandrea), found in a grave in Sindos in 1981, ending with coins of Philip.

The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel and comprised 8 to 9 kilos of coins. Magaud catalogued 2,406 coins: 1 denarius, 2,405 antoniniani (radiates) and in 1910, the abbot Angot added another 43 coins which Magaud incorporated into the hoard. The hoard was found by a farm labourer in a field: Maximian I Thrax - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 651.7-5724.2g.
c. 4000 (2244) antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 720.1-1079.9g.

A hoard of 155 bronze coins (2 hellenistic coins, 34 Roman imperial coins including 2 denarii, 12 provincial coins, 107 provincial coins from Gerasa), found within a linen purse close to the podium of the temple of Zeus, in a layer of reused material dated from the early 3rd c. AD.
7 coins: 4 denarii, 2 sestertii, 1 bronze found a in a layer of fire: Antoninus Pius - Severus alexander (AD 222-228).
4 bronze coins: Hadrian - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235). Found together with an iron scale, a bronze weigh and scale pan fragments. Most likely ot a set for weighing.

Found during construction work, supervised by archaeologists. Among other coins ca. 30 poorly preserved radiates, probably a purse (?), mainly imitations of the Gallic Empire (Tetricus I), plus one Divo Claudio II (altar, cf. RIC V.1, p. 233, no 261 (bust K).

The hoard was found during the excavation of a Roman villa and comprised three separate deposits of coins from Gallienus to Probus. The first deposit comprised 29 coins of Postumus. The second deposit comprised 19 radiates from Gallienus to Probus and the third, 5 radiates from Gallienus to Victorinus.
(c. 1400) 1352 antoniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver weight: c.1751.4-3638.7 g.
disposition: Museum Dauphinoise, Grenoble, France; part of the coins and the container.

summary: In 1873, Alph. Frappier gavie to the Société de statistique des Deux-Sèvres, 37 silver Roman coins which were said to come from a hoard found in the region.

1,091 coins placed in a cloth and a ceramic vessel: aureus, denarii, antoniniani (radiates), imitations: Septimius Severus to Diocletian/Maximian I (tpq. AD 297); silver weight: 204.0-2827.6 g. Together were found three silver rings.
102 coins: 5 antoniniani, 23 sestertii, 74 bronze (sestertii?): Domitian - Gallienus/Postumus (AD 260-268); silver weight: 4.0-12.1 g.
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique, Bruxelles, Belgium (102 coins)

summary: 102 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian and Diocletian (AD 286-287) found in a pile at floor level (along the wall of a room) during excavations of a house.
From Elagabalus to Valerian I. Possibly incomplete as only known from antiquities trade: 61 coins; Silver weight: 46.4-156.7g. The hoard is dispersed having been sold in New York in 1980.
39 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 255-256). Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".
disposition: 'Selection in Oxford, where there is also a handwritten list (Milne); some of the rest are probably in Toronto'

summary: A hoard of 432 Roman silver coins (denarii and some antoniniani), ranging from Commodus to Trajan Decius, found in the summer of 1895 during draining works at Brickendonbury, south of Hertford. The coins lay partly in a small recess cut in the virgin clay, and partly in the soil above.
126 sestertii: Domitian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

The hoard was found in a large iron pot and comprised approximately 29 kilos (close to 120 marcs) of Roman silver coins. The coins were denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from the reign of Septimius Severus to Gallienus and Postumus. Cochet suggested purely hypothetically that this hoard was found in Saint-André-Sur-Cailly.

Hoard of 225 coins: 1 imperial denarius, 8 gold stateri, 216 bronze staters of Bosporan kings: Rhescuporis III, Cotys III, Sauromates III, Rhescuporis IV, Ininthimeus Rhescuporis V, dated between AD 80 and AD 251.

The coins (15 denarii, ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Maximinus, with the probable addition of a further denarius of Septimius Severus) were found together at the southwest foothills of the Lehenbühl, SE of Fridingen.
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 189 silver and copper-alloy coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates) - from Antoninus Pius to Gallienus.

Hoard found in a cooking pot (not preserved) during construction work for the Nordostbahn railway track. It comprised an unknown number of antoniniani, of which 204 (possibly the greater part) are preserved in public collection, ranging from Trebonianus Gallus to Claudius II. - After the publication in 1992, at least another 6 coins from this hoard were recorded, in a private collection in Diessenhofen. The sherds of the pot are described in the 1893 publication. Four Gallienus coins were also subjected to chemical analysis at the same time, pp. 11-12: "Derselbe hat drei Stücke auf ihre Zusammensetzung quantitativ und qualitativ, das vierte nur qualitativ untersucht und folgendes gefunden: I. 6 Theile Zinn, 94 Theile Kupfer; II. 30 Th. Silber, 0,3 Th. Gold, 69,7 Th. Kupfer; III. 18 Th. Antimon, 82 Th. Kupfer; IV. Kupfer, Antimon und wenig Bismuth."
disposition: Thurgauisches Historisches Museum, Frauenfeld (158 coins); Museum Allerheiligen, Schaffhausen (40 coins); Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (6 coins); private (6 coins)

summary: 123 sestertii, ranging from Caracalla to Valerian I.

A hoard of 7+ antoniniani (Caracalla - Valerian and Gallienus) was found in 1850 during the excavation of a foundation trench at the town exit. The coins were lying together in rolls. There find is incomplete, only 7 coins were described.

IARCH record for a hoard of objects from Christchurch, Cambridgeshire (CAM-F7C941).V. Drost has identified a possible hoard of 3 silver and plated denarii, 18 copper alloy sestertii and sestertius fractions and 411 copper alloy radiates and barbarous radiates within the group. He writes: "432 coins were submitted as a potential Treasure case together with various metal and lead objects (2 copper alloy rings, 1 copper alloy lump, 5 lead fragments). It cannot be proved that those objects were originally part of the hoard (the rings are clearly modern) and they have therefore been excluded."

The hoard comprised a grey ware vessel containing 9,065 small bronzes, weighing 25kg. The coins included issues of Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II, Quintillus, Aurelian, Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus I. Several months later, the same finder discovered a second vessel filled with approximately 4,000 coins. According to Etoc-Demazy, 4/5ths of the first hoard was acquired by the Musée du Mans. In 1981, a lot of 181 coins was sold at the Hotel Drouot which may have been part of the second hoard.
Circa 500 antoniniani. Only 11 pieces were described in the first publication.
68 antoniniani (radiates), mainly unidentified barbarous imitations (AD 275-290).
A hoard of c. 7000 late third-century radiates.
A hoard of 10 antoniniani (Valerian I - Gallienus) found in a destruction deposit of a Roman villa 500 metres from Chaeronea.
109 denarii and antoniniani: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 134.3-277.1 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1841

summary: A hoard of ca. 2400 silver coins, most of them ranging from Septimius Severus to Gallienus, was unearthed in house no. 45 in 1902. 700 specimens arrived in the Kempten Heimatmuseum, several others in private ownership. The provenance of the coins in the Kempten museum can't be ascertained any more, but FMRD publishes a list of 21 coins with RIC references, and a summary list of 363 coins that probably came from this hoard.
(7 kg) (1200+) 22 coins: 1 denarius, 20 antoniniani, 1 bronze: Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
9 bronze coins, date, grave: Gaius - Quintillus (AD 270).

The discovery of gold jewellery, objects and coinage in the Lava Gulf off the coast of Corsica is reputed to have begun in the nineteenth century after a chance find by a coral fisherman. 41 aurei or multiples of aurei first appeared on the antiquities market in 1956 (35 aurei and 6 multiples) followed by further discoveries in 1971 and in 1985. It is reputed to have included between 400 and 600 aurei and multiples of aurei of Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus and Aurelian, jewellery and gold finger rings which were melted down, a gold dish with a medallion of Gallienus at its centre, and possibly a gold statuette.

111 denarii, 29 antoniniani (radiates) and one sestertius, ranging from Hadrian to Trebonianus Gallus (Hostilian). The coins that make up this hoard were found a ceramic beaker, which was found in a pit in the northwest corner of a house that contained a metal workshop for bronze. Fragments of a 1:1 bronze statue (possibly an imperial statue) were found close to where the beaker with the coins was discovered.
Hoard of 96 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Cotys II, Rhoemetalkes, Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III.
Unknown initial number of coins. 18 antoniniani (radiates) are kept in a private collection: Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270).

The hoard was found in 1973 during archaeological program. The archaeologists discovered 45 kg of sestertii, in 12 rolls in a wood box. It comprised c. 1980 sestertii from Philip I - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Gallienus) (AD 253-268).
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 138 were examined and 18 entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N. 0026/1-18 (18 coins)

summary: 2,997 coins: 2,986 antoniniani (radiates), 11 denarii found with a cooking pot: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258).
Hoard of 1,040 silver coins (?) found in a small ceramic vessel of which only 394 silver coins are known: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: Museum, Panagyurishte; Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria

summary: Originally 44 coins, 41 pieces recovered: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Unknown silver coins. 45 coins were bought by the museum in Traismauer. One of the coins is an anotninianus of Probus.

Hoard of gold and silver coins of circa 6 kilos: 3.85 silver, 2.26 gold. The gold coins were wrapped in leather and together with most of the silver ones they were distributed among the finders. 14 antoniniani (radiates) have been studied so far: Gordian III 8, and Philip I for Otacilia Severa 3, Gallienus 1, Claudius II 2.
The hoard comprised approximately 1,000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Philip I.
(c. 200) 40 silver coins: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); Silver weight: 46.4-91.3 g.
8 bronze pieces: 6 sestertii, 2 medallions: Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) - Septimius Severus (AD 210).
Three aurei part of a chain, 2 mounted in pendants: Valerian I (2), Valerianus II Caesar) (AD 255-256)
Although 17 sestertii were found, only 12 were described by Mattingly presumably because 5 were too worn to identify. Found stuck together in the "House of the two hoards".
Unknown original number of coins. 90 coins found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Maximianus I Thrax (AD 235-238)?
The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vase containing 73 antoniniani (radiates) (or 60 according to Blanchet) from Gallienus to Probus.
167 silver coins: 39 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CXLI

summary: The surviving part of the hoard includes 164 denari and 118 antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasianus to Philip I (AD 72-248). 221 coins are now kept in the Museo Archeologico del Friuli Occidentale, 61 in different private collections. The original amount of the hoard remains unknown. Given the very little distance between the two findspots, Masi I and Masi II should be two sections of the same hoard deposited in different places by its owner.
disposition: Pordenone, Museo Archeologico del Friuli Occidentale

summary: 117 coins entered museum collection Yambol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2409/0-65/, 2435/0-40/, 2547/0-7/, 2663/0-3/

summary: 18 antoniniani (raddiates) found in the dump of the ancient quarry: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised 2,445 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani-radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I (AD 257) found in a lead container.
48 antoniniani: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 16

summary: The hoard was found in a hollow stone and comprised 300 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
2 denarii and 436 radiates (Septimius Severus to the Tetrici), two silver finger rings, and one small silver ingot found beneath a stone by workers widening a road between Amlwch and Bull Bay.
The hoard comprised 100 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of Caracalla, Elagabalus, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I, Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
27 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I of which 23 imitations
It comprised c. 250 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 75 are recorded: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised a vessel containing a gold finger ring, a silver bracelet and 28 coins from Marcus Aurelius to Valerian I.
762 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a jar in underground room H during excavations of a house.
727 denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no.8442-9165

summary: The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing 600 coins, apparently antoniniani (radiates). A further 9 coins were recovered from the bed of a small stream that ran into the pond. These coins were of the same emperors as those contained in the hoard.

The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing between 600 and 700 radiates of Gordian III to Postumus. The hoard was immediately dispersed, although subsequently two lots of coins were recovered for study.
77 coins: 11 denarii, 39 antoniniani (radiates), 12 AR, 10 sestertii 5 AE: Tiberius - Postumus (AD 266-267); silver weight: 31.3-136.1 g.

find_spot_name: CANTERBURY, MARLOWE CAR PARK AREA M II
summary: Marlowe Car Park Area M II, scattered hoard of 119 coins, found in flood silts sealing Structure R22. Contains coins of Constantine & Valentinian (intrusive), but also of Carausius, Gallienus & barbarous radiates, latter make up approx.. half of group.

A hoard of 788 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus), denarii (Julia Mamaea) and antoniniani (Caracalla - Gallienus) found during the excavations at Dura Europos, in a jar under the embankment beside the Palmyra Gate.
Hoard given to Sfax Museum in October 1961, examined by Salama: 36 antoniniani: Valerian I and Gallienus - Gallienus (sole)? (AD 260-268).
220 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius for Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-247).
A hoard of 104 Roman coins (Philip I - Probus), found opposite the station of Mehrhoog, on a sand hill. The coins are lost.
The hoard comprised approximately 422 sestertii and 4 antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasian to Trebonianus Gallus with a tpq of AD 253. An anonymous catalogue gives details of 409 coins.
A purse of 14 provincial coins from Athens (period VB, VC and VI), found on the floor of the south house, on the northern slope of the Hill of the Nymphs.
7 silver coins: 6 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Republic - Valerianus/Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 253-268); silver weight: 11.8-22.8 g.
disposition: Musée Archéologique de Namur, Belgium (7 coins)

summary: 4,000-4,500 antoniniani found in a cooking pot. 1501 pieces are presented here combining the evidences of Brunšmid from the year 1880 and the FMRSl I: Gallienus - Carinus (AD 283-284)
disposition: Narodni muzej Ljubljana, Slovenia (few coins); Kunsthistorischen Museums, Wien, Austria (coins of Claudius II); Collection Markl (coins of Tacitus); Collection Kolb. (coins of Florian); Archaeological Museum, Zagreb, Croatia; dispersed

summary: 18 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13869/1-18 (17 coins)

summary: The hoard was found in a barrel or box and comprised approximately 900 bronze coins arranged in stacks. The first account of the hoard gives the hoard as ranging from Domitian to Commodus, with coins of Hadrian and the Antonines (with the exception of Commodus) being particularly numerous. A catalogue of 36 of the sestertii was created. In 1843 or 1844, it was noted that there were also two later coins in the hoard. The hoard was dispersed immediately amongst collectors, with a small number of worn coins kept by the finder. The Musée du Mans acquired some coins (which are now mixed in with the La Quinte hoard).
disposition: Musée du Mans (coins are now mixed in with the La Quinte hoard)

summary: About 2000 antoniniani were discovered in unknown circumstances. No further Information.
1013 silver cois: 1004 denarii, 9 antoniniani: Galba - Gordianus III (AD 239); silver weight: 1417.0-3160.9 g
The hoard comprised 224 coins from Nerva to Aurelian. This included 28 sestertii from Nerva to Septimius Severus, 1 worn dupondius or as and 95 radiates from Gordian III to Victorinus and Aurelian.
Two double-pierced gold coins, an aureus of Septimius Severus (AD 203), and its imitation were reported from a village.
1,576 coins found in two ceramic vessels: 1 denarius, 1,575 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander (Julia Mammaea), Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: c. 300.6-2,110.7 g.
Four antoniniani (radiates), that may have belonged to a hoard: Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius for Hostilian (Caesar/Augustus), Gallienus (AD 253-259).

Found during excavations, in "Brandschicht" in a room in the western part of Insula 30. 4 coins, 2 antoniniani (Philip I and Volusian) and 2 missing, found together with fragments of a bronze vessel (lost).

There is debate about whether 2-3000 coins were found (Lebarbier-Arnoux) or 5-6000 coins (Bottin). The librarian in Valenciennes, Hécart, saw about 500. An English officer, Drummond Hay, took a large portion of the hoard. Found with a ceramic vessel Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).
55 antoniniani (radiates): Pupienus - Valerian I (AD 253-260); silver weight: 69.9-128.8 g.

A hoard of 751 AE radiates, & 1 AE denarius and pottery to AD 286 in a black burnished ware jar. Unpublished coin report by R. Abdy.

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 3,258 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271). The coins of Postumus (and some imitations) made up a quarter of all the coins studied. The hoard was found during ground levelling works close to the walls of a farm; silver weight: 880.6-5928.0 g.

The hoard is composed of 10 poorly preserved Antonine bronzes. It was found during three archaeological(?) surveys of Noires-Terres in the Bois-en-Ardres in February 1980, at the end of 1981 and in early 1982) and interpreted as the remains of a dispersed hoard, as they were all found in the same place.

Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 47 coins were documented: Vespasian - Elagabalus (Julia Soaemias) (AD 218-222).

Unknown initial number of coins. Five coins are known: 1 Greek coin, 3 denarii, 2 plated denarii: 2nd c. BC - Septimius Severus (Plautilla) (AD 202-205). It may be a votive offering as suggested by some scholars based on the findspot.

This hoard comprised 522 coins: 7 denarii, 515 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-263). Beside were discovered: 7 gold rings, 6 silver rings, 1 silvered bronze ring, 1 gold earring and 1 bronze earring.

A large hoard of at least 295 denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Caracalla, was found in 1965 on Jakobstraße, while digging up the road. It lay in a broken fragment of an earthenware container. 162 coins arrived in the state museum of Darmstadt, oxidized together in a greenish clump, but more coins were dispersed. Of these, 133 could be traced and published with the coins in the Darmstadt museum. It is likely that in addition to these ca. 200 denarii have been lost for ever.

The hoard was found hidden in the hollow base of a statue and comprised coins of Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus, Claudius II, Probus and Tacitus. The nummus of Constantine I/Gratian, probably, a intruder.
758 coins from Augustus to Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

summary: The hoard consists of 336 coins, most of which are separate, with some bunches of coins stuck together. Additionally, there are eight fragments of pottery, including the complete base of the ceramic vessel with some coins still intact. Most coins are clearly contemporary copies or 'barbarous radiates'.

51H includes the coins which were found in front of the temple, in the court by an urn.

The context of the treasure burying, although partly known, remains problematic : in fact, there are two deposits of precious objects, very close to each other but quite distinct, inside caches which were laid under the ground. Should they be attributed to the occupants of the houses from the second half of the 3rd century AD, or to the occupants of the potter's workshop following in the beginning of the 4th century AD? The first deposit gathers together two silver bracelets and a group of statuettes in the same metal, more or less fragmentary. Three of them are fully preserved : one Helios dedicated to an emperor's numen, one Fortuna with a double horn of plenty and one goddess, more enigmatic, carrying a dish with two birds inside. The head of a Jupiter and of an amazing personage with two outgrowths as an ornament in the hair add to the whole which is completed by a bust-portrait, probably representing an emperor (Gallienus?). The second deposit, locked inside a wooden box, consists of crookery, jewels and coins. The silverware is made up of one dish decorated with a Mercure, two small trays ornated with reliefs (one of them just in bronze and silver plated), fourteen spoons and two fragmentary cutleries. All these objects belong to well known series in Gaul : their shapes and decoration show that they were made in the 3rd century AD. The set of jewels includes two golden bracelets, two pairs of golden, emerald, pearl and molten glass pendant earrings, two bezel rings (one of them with a nicolo), and one coin medallion (Gordian III aureus, AD 238-244). At the bottom of the box, there was a purse with 81 well preserved silver coins - 29 denarii and 52 antoniniani (radiates) - with a chronological curve stretching from Vitellius (AD 69) to the joint reign of Valerian and Gallian (AD 253-260). In fact, there are two different sets : one with 62 coins, that is to say 19 "old" denarii from Vitellius to Commodus, eight more recent all dated AD 201, 33 antoniniani (radiates) and one denarius struck between AD 215 and AD 217 for Caracalla, as well as, one denarius of Diadumenian in AD 218; the second set comprises 19 antoniniani (radiates) coins issued between AD 241 and AD 258. One can wonder about the precise nature of these deposits. The sculptures found there do not have quite a homogeneous construction ; maybe a kind of Lares altar or objects belonging to a sanctuary, as most of them represent divinities, and one at least, the birds’ goddess, seems to have a strong local connotation. The silverware hardly represents more than two pounds of metal ; it is therefore difficult to speak of a "table set" all the less as the spoons are rather incomplete. The set of jewels, which is more coherent and of good quality but with no exceptional piece, illustrates well the favourite jewels in the well-off classes of Gaul around the middle of the 3rd century AD. Regarding the coins, there are several arguments speaking for a saving, rather than for a reserve currency, which was formerly made (maybe following two main payments (donativa) in AD 202 and AD 217/218, and poorly completed by a contribution in antoniniani (radiates) around AD 258-260), a small family inheritance safeguarded for sentimental reasons, maybe one generation away. (Aubin, G. et al. 1999)

Found during construction work, partially supervised by an archaeologist, in the ruins of a Roman rural building; 15 sestertii, Antoninus Pius to Philipp I, found together with shards possibly of a container. The hoard has been interpreted as a 'Bauopfer' or foundation deposit.
The hoard comprised a vessel 'filled with 500 3rd century coins which were immediately dispersed.' Workmen tracing the route from Neufchâtel to Gamaches.
1,168 silver coins - antoniniani (radiates) and denarii found while metal detecting. Probably, ending with coins of Philip I (AD 244-249).
Hoard of 1,500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) found in several amphoras: Clodius Albinus - Gallienus (AD 260-268). Found together with a gold chain.
9 coins found near a broken money-box: 5 antoniniani, 2 denarii, 1 sestertius, 1 unidentified denomination: Septimius Severus/Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
Between 1,500 and 3,000 coins found in a ceramic vessel. 185 coins seen: Julia Domna to Tetricus II Silver: c.1,500 coins; Silver weight: c.287.4-3897.6g.
27 silver coins discovered while ploughing: 14 denarii, 13 antoniniani: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

summary: A hoard of 96 Syrian tetradrachms (Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus) and antoniniani (Gordian III, Philip I) from Dura Europos, found during excavations for the Expedition's house.
A small barbarous radiate hoard in the British Museum with the provenance "Beccles, Lowestoft, 1872". No further information.
A hoard of three large gold medallions, 23 aurei, 4 gold bars, 2 gold tintinnabula and several amulets of gold and lapis lazuli, probably deposited in the reign of Gordian III or Philip the Arab.
disposition: BNF, Paris (Alexander Medaillions); G. de Demetrio (Gold Objects)

summary: Few hundred coins. Only 98 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) are recovered: Elagabalus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 267-268).

disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 587 (72 coins)

summary: An uncertain number of coins. Only two denarii of Caracalla were identified.

The hoard comprised 29 coins, ranging from Hellenistic times (?) to Philip. This includes coins of Athens and Cnossus, as well as Roman sestertii, dupondii and asses. Hadrian, Severus Alexander and Gordian III are also mentioned. The hoard was found beneath the foundations of a building, under a slab of stone.
(10.000+/-) 1112 antoniniani: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: c.1351.0-6249.0g
disposition: National Museum in Valjevo, Serbia (1112 coins) - 2001; dispersed

summary: 32 silver coins: 24 antoniniani (radiates), 8 denarii: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
5 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268), most likely, part of other hoards found here (e.g. Dalheim II). Was found in a jug that was destroyed by a plow.

The coins were found inside a copper-alloy cauldron with a total weight of 45kg. However, the hoard was rapidly dispersed, leaving a total of 2,421 coins, corresponding to approximately 14% of the original find. This is estimated at 10,000 coins.
1,400-1500 antoniniani (radiates). Only 479 coins were available for study: Philip I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Collection P. du Chatellier; Musée de Carnac (in 1893, 460 coins); Musée de Bretagne, Rennes, France (inv.no. MAN 80315, 18 coins)

summary: Approx. 80 small bronze coins, of which 13 are imitations of Tetricus I, found on a brickyard located between the Lehmstrasse and Am Schlütershof. Apparently, they were contained in a small metal box.
The coins (at least 5) were found in 1830 on the premises of Proitzschenberg, near the 'Lehmmauer'.

(1213) 1209 silver coins: 10 denarii, 1199 antoniniani: Caracalla - Gallienus (AD 259-268); silver weight: 1752.4-2218.6 g. The hoard was foun within the ruins of a Roman building placed in a bronze vessel

summary: 24 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 22 sestertii and 1 dupondius. The latest coin is a sestertius of Trajan Decius for Herennia Etruscilla (Augusta) (AD 249-251).

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 350 silver coins, 'nearly all debased coins.' The coins included issues of Antoninus Pius, Faustina, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Geta, Plautilla, Macrinus, Diadumenian, Elagabalus, Julia Paula, Julia Maesa, Julia Soaemias, Severus Alexander, Maximinus, Maximus, Gordian III, Philip, Trajan Decius and Herennia Etruscilla. Piette mentions a coin of Diocletian but this is an error for Diadumenian.

Six coins were found together with the artefacts of this hoard: Domitian bronze coin, Trajan (1 sestertius, 1 dupondius), Hadrian 1 sestertius, Antoninus Pius 1 dupondius, Postumus 1 antoninianus (radiate). The Chaourse Treasure is made up of 39 objects in total, all of which are silver apart from five small vessels and a silvered bronze mirror. There are four large serving platters; one of which has the swastika in its central medallion, another has a gilded figure of the Roman god Mercury holding his caduceus flanked by a ram and a cockerel. In addition, there are plain silver drinking cups, various jugs, two large situlas one of which has an acanthus-scroll frieze, shallow plates, hemispherical bowls (one of which was used for washing hands), flanged and fluted bowls (some with engraved decoration of animals amid floral patterns), some mirrors, an ornate strainer with floral and geometric designs, a statuette of the deity Fortuna and a pepper-pot in the shape of an African slave-boy. (Wikipedia)
(100) 32 coins, 1 aureus, denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Valerian I (AD 253-260).

The earlier finds had been dispersed, but most of them could be traced in FMRD.

A hoard of 7 aurei, 95 denarii, 206 antoniniani, together with 14 others (1 denarius and 13 antoniniani) which were reported as from the same hoard, all found on the Sully Moors by a labourer digging building foundations. Two of the antoniniani of Trajan Decius were overstruck on denarii of Geta and Maximinus. One of the gold coins of Diocletian was a double aureus. The number of extra coins reported as having belonged to the hoard was given as 15, but only 14 were listed.

Found by labourers while ploughing a field near Ibikon. The hoard consisted of 10 silver coins and 169 aes coins, in a pot. The written sources name Maximinus Thrax as latest reign represented. Today only 44 aes coins are preserved: 33 coins in the Museum für Urgeschichte(n), Zug, and 11 coins in the Schweizerisches Landesmuseum, Zürich. The latest coin preserved dates from Commodus (SFI 1707-5.1) Another 12 coins, now in the Museum für Urgeschichte(n), Zug, might be part of the same hoard (SFI 1707-5.2). The latest coin of this lot dates from Gordian III.
disposition: Museum für Urgeschichte(n), Zug; Schweizerisches Landesmuseum, Zürich

summary: A hoard of 15 coins, found in a grave (grave 4) during the excavations at Pylos, in Volimidia, north of Chora. It has been described as 13 sestertii and 2 antoniniani, though Vlachogianni and Tourastoglou give a slightly different account of the emperors represented (see under References).
The hoard comprised c. 3/4000 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
645 denarii, 1 gold necklace and other artefacts. 154 coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: 29 antoniniani, 125 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
