summary: 90 silver coins: 36 denarii, 54 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius - Valerian I (AD 257); silver weight: 114.7-196.4 g.

The hoard was found as the result of deep-ploughing which brought 126 small Roman bronzes to the surface which were collected by farmers. An archaeological excavation then revealed a greyware vessel filled with more radiates and a further pink ceramic vessel containing 1,276 coins. Two containers, one with 988 antoniniani (radiates) from Julia Domna to Postumus, the other 1,437 from Valerian to Tetricus II Silver: 2,425 coins; silver weight: 730.8-3581.8g.
The hoard, found with a bronze vessel, comprised approximately 1,200 radiates from Claudius II to Diocletian (AD 287-288); silver weight: 133.5-237.1 g.

337 silver coins: 272 denarii, 65 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I (AD 255). The hoard found in an urn contains also jewelry. It was found in an area where other archaeological evidence suggests Roman occupation.
Unknown number of coins found in the 1980's. 4 pieces: 2 denarii, 2 antoniniani entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Julia Domna, Philip I, Gallienus.
Unknown number of denarii. 199 entered the museum collection in Silistra: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 217).
(+200) 126 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-268); silver weight: 38.8-156.5 g.

The wooden box contained pieces of silverware and various Roman artefacts. The finder sold the jewellery to the Imperial Library, today the National Library. The coins were dispersed; 1,450 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). The hoard consists of: 8 gold necklaces, pearls or semi-precious stones; 5 gold rings; 6 silver rings; 1 ivory styllus; 1 silver ingot; 1 gold roll of wire; hollow gold fingers (plectrum); a stone statuette of Aesculapius; several rings with intaglio; 2 silver hearts and 1 necklace pendant with a gold coin.
15 coins: 3 heavily worn out denarii, 12 provincial bronze coins found in a sacred area (sanctuary) in a small dish: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 600 sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius. A further sestertius of Marcus Aurelius was overstruck with a double sestertius of Postumus. The coins were arranged in textile bags. Fragments of the bags survived where coins touched the walls of the vessel.

The hoard comprised 'several hundred small bronze coins'. Canel distinguishes this hoard from those found in Préaux (TAF IV. 57). The hoard was near the top of the hill, close to the plough, approximately 1km from the ancient abbey of Saint-Léger.

The hoard was scattered by the plough, but 124 coins were recovered. They comprised 2 denarii and 122 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Gallienus and Postumus with a tpq of AD 263. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 37.6g to 154.7g.
226 silver coins were found at a spot somewhere between school and a mound: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244)

138 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian (AD 253-260).
1700 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I/Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).

Unnown number of Roman coins found duing the construction clay station. Among them: Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius dupondius, Marcus Aurelius sestertius, Gordian III dupondius, Philip I (Otacilia Severa) sestertius, Gallienus (Salonina) antoninianus (radiate).
Hoard of over 5,000 antoniniani (radiates) and imitations: Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard comprised more than 35,000 antoniniani (Aurelian - Diocletian, all dating from before the reform of AD 294), found off the coast of Syrna at cape Fteni Punta. The hoard was found on a shipwreck (Syrna I) and has been interpreted as carrying wages or money for military expenses. The hoard was first found by a sponge diver, rescue excavations followed in 2002.

296 AE radiates to AD 286. The coins were 1.5ft below the plough soil with no visible signs of a container. A circular, corroded stud with a narrow band and possible inscription was also discovered with the hoard. This is believed to be Medieval or post-Medieval and, as such, is not considered part of the hoard. A farthing (Seaby, 3992) was also found with the coins during conservation.Addenda of 618 coins found in 2104 added here.
19 antoniniani (radiates) of the period Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259); silver weight: 5.6-13.4 g.

Three accounts of the discovery exist, but all give different details and there is no other contemporary authority which could be used. Both brass coins (possibly including coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina) and minimi were found in 1869 and have been assumed to be part of one and the same hoard. The three accounts of the range of the first brass gave either Severus Alexander, Gallienus or Maximian as the last emperor represented, and it is now impossible to be certain which account is correct. In 1935, C.H.V. Sutherland examined 105 radiate minims from this hoard. These proved to be exactly similar to the 317 radiate minims which were acquired by Sir Arthur Evans at Bristol some years before, along with 6 regular antoniniani (NC, 1934, 92-103) [no. 804]. Dr. Sutherland therefore concluded that these 317 and 105 radiate minims all came from the Whitchurch hoard. The 6 regular antoniniani may or may not have come from the same find. They were of Victorinus (3) and Tetricus II (3). With the 317 minims, were a rough lump of copper and a piece of sheet metal. The 422 minims copied the following prototypes: Gallic Empire types (249), types of Claudius II (23), miscellaneous types (150). The large brass may have been collected together, to be melted down to make into radiate minims.
7 aurei: Carinus - Maximian (AD 286-294) and jewelry, bracelets and rings.
disposition: Numismatic Department of the Hungarian National Museum (Inv.no. 62.1946), Budapest, Hungary

32 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Probus (AD 276-282).

The hoard was found during the excavation of the Roman town of Baelo and comprised 13 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Claudius II with a tpq of AD 269-270. The coins were stacked one on top of the other next to a piece of limestone.
928 (589) denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (sole reign) (AD 267).

The earliest coin was an aureus of Galba and the latest were issues of Gallienus. The hoard was found close to a mill at a depth of 15 inches. Most of the hoard was acquired by the Musée de Genève. The aureus of Galba was stolen before 1903.
100 silver coins were discovered. 24 have been seen: 9 antoniniani, 15 denarii: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).

Hucher compiled a catalogue of 4,518 coins (14 worn bronzes; 4504 radiates and imitations). Imitations account for approximately 44% of the coins in the hoard of which 2.8% were minimi. summary: The hoard comprised approximately 1,000 coins 'nearly all with the bust of Augustus' and bearing the reverse type LAETITIA AVG. As the LAETITIA AVG reverse type is most common on issues of Gordian III, under the Gallic Emperors and under Probus, it is likely that the coins were radiates dating to the third century AD.
A hoard of 14 Roman provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella; Commodus - Gordian III), found in a grave in Peristeronas.
2,000 bronze coins, probably, kept in a wooden box: Hadrian - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard comprises 182 antoniniani (radiates). The 182 pieces were found stacked on three rows: in the first two there were series of 13 to 15 coins forming tubes on the edges above the lowest series. At the lower level they appeared more arbitrarily placed in a larger radius. Three tegulae formed a vault over the whole.

summary: A large hoard of c. 22,500 gold and silver coins, ranging from Claudius to Maximinus I, found in 1909 during excavation works for the construction of a house on Gertrudenstraße, approx. midway between Wolfstraße and Neumarkt. Of the c. 22,500 coins found, 4513 are identifiable to RIC number. Only part of these coins are preserved today.

Originally a hoard of 68 coins but one went astray. From the 67 remaining coins (62 dupondii and 5 asses), 23 are completely illegible. The coins are heavily worn, suggested a much later burial than the latest coin.
The hoard comprised 38 antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Gallienus (sole reign).

The hoard was found during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' at Troussepoil and comprised 231 brass coins (sestertii?). Close to the hoard, 3 broken black ceramic jugs were excavated, two of which were filled with ashes and funeral pyre debris. Baudry thought that the coins had originally been placed in the jugs, but that hypothesis is not certain. The hoard was discovered during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' of Troussepoil.

A large number of coins were illegible. Blanchet mistakenly doubled the total of the coins in the hoard and placed it in the parish of Aubigné-Racan.
50 silver coins, 10 seen: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 250-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CLXIV in 1957

summary: 39 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Most likely it is part of the hoard PLOURHAN 1881 (Plourhan II).
disposition: Collection P. du Chatellier; Musée de Bretagne, Rennes, France (inv.no. MAN 80316, 39 coins)

summary: 108 denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 241-243).

The hoard was found in two vessels and comprised 6,700 Provincial bronzes chiefly of Samos, ending with coins of Gallienus (sole reign). Other mints represented include Naxos, Ephesus, Magnesia ad Maeander and Smyrna. The two vessels were resting against the wall of a house, built west of the 'Cicero-Exedra'.
disposition: Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Münzkabinett; Samos, archaeological museum

summary: A large hoard of antoniniani (radiates). Only 204 coins were noticed: Gallienus (sole) - Carinus (AD 283-284); silver weight: 36.8-65.2 g.

In 1885, 6 Roman gold coins and a golden clasp were dug up during digging works in the Main at Thüngersheim. In 1886 two further gold coins were found at the same location. Coins range from Antoninus Pius to Gallienus.
10 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 3.7-11.5 g.
The hoard comprised a large cup containing 635 antoniniani (radiates) of which only 332 were identified. Silver weight: 172.4-792.8g.
25 silver coins: 2 republican denarii, 21 imperial denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates): Republic - Postumus (AD 260-269).

Hoard found during railway construction work, probably from the area of the site of a Roman villa rustica. It comprisesd at least 2114 coins, but no more than 2300. Coins run from Valerian to Aurelian, mainly Gallienus and Claudius II. Reported coins of Tacitus, Probus and Diocletianus (dated 289) seem to be intruders from the Reichenstein hoard (Schaub-Gysin 1930, p. 70).
The hoard comprised 1,104 radiates from Valerian and Gallienus to Quintillus. 740 have been studied by Salama. (AD 270)
21 silver coins: 9 denarii, 12 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.no. CC 256/00)

summary: 50 radiates, mainly of the Gallic Empire and terminating with Carausius, found near Conwy shortly after 1945. No more specific information on the find spot is available.
1943 silver coins found with a bronze vessel: 1942 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Antoninus Pius - MAximinus I Thrax (AD 236).

A hoard of 131 provincial coins of Athens (periods VB, VI) and 2 antoniniani of Gallienus, excavated in 1957 from a pit in the floor of a house at the northwest foot of the Areopagus (House B, Agora grid Q 19).
11 coins: 1 aureus, 9 denarii, 1 bronze: Marcus Aurelius - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); gold weight: 7.1-7.2 g; silver weight: 17.2-22.6 g.
382 coins. 332 coins in the museum in Vidin: Galba - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 438-463 (today, less than 300 coins)

summary: 111 coins confiscated in 1981. The find encompassed 69 provincial coins from Thessalonica (Commodus - Philip II), 14 from Pella (Caracalla - Otacilia Severa), 6 from Edessa (Caracalla - Gordian III), 3 from Dion (Elagabalus - Maximinus); 1 from Stobi (Septimius Severus), 9 from the Koinon of Macedonia, 5 uncertain ones of 'Greek cities', 4 imperial coins (Vespasian - Maximinus).
Unknown originally number of coins. 30 aurei: Nero - Septimius Severus for Caracalla (Augustus) (AD 202).
Recorded by the Somerset Levels Project. Hoard comprised just 3 radiates, found during peat digging. No archaeological context.

A hoard of 162 provincial coins, 27 of which were illegible. The remaining ones were: 134 coins from Sinope (Antoninus Pius - Valerian & Gallienus) and 1 from Trapezus (Gordian III). The hoard was found in a burnt and shattered container in the remains of a Roman villa, on the northern side of the Sinope peninsula.
c. 1200 silver coins: 1 denarius and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised 79 sestertii from Vespasian to Treboninanus Gallus (AD 251-253).
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 21 were kept in the museum of Elbing: 7 antoniniani (radiates), 14 denarii: Mark Antony - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology and History in Elblag (former Town Museum Elbing) in 1903.

summary: In 1837 six silver coins and one copper coin were unearthed in an arable field between Dambach and Hammerschmiede, in the vicinity of the Dambach Roman fort. The six silver coins were denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Julia Mamaea. The copper coin was an antoninianus of Carinus, that was probably not part of the hoard and has not been listed here.
At 3 m from the findspot of MORCHAIN 1, 7 coins: 1 double sestertius, 2 sestertii, 3 asses, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Titus, Hadrian, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Postumus (AD 264-265).
The hoard comprised 29 silver and 8 bronze coins dated between 103-76 BC and AD 260-268.

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing 931 radiates for which Bourriau provides a summary catalogue: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Atgier noted the presence of coins of Quintillus and Constantine but TAF believes this to be an error. The coins were acquired by the Bibliothèque Municipale de La Rochelle. The jug handle is in the Musée d'Orbigny.
disposition: Bibliothèque Municipale de La Rochelle (coins); Musée d'Orbigny (jug)

summary: 269 bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel during metal detecting: 252 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 13 asses: Domitian - Postumus (AD 260-261).
16 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.
Around 100 bronze coins of 'large and medium size' from Trajan to Postumus (?) (AD 260-268).

Hoard 2 from Housesteads. Brickstock and Casey in Rushworth ed. 2009, 375 describe the hoard thus: "consists of four Radiate Copies found corroded together (SF No. 9396) in 1981 in H14:4:7, the chalet barrack phase of Building XIV. The identifiable prototypes of the copies are issues of Tetricus I and II (AD 270-73). Deposition may have taken place early in the period AD 273-86 (Period 19) since the copies are of large module and relatively unworn."
Circa 3,000 antoniniani (radiates).
Large number of silver coins. 14 pieces were noticed: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

7 coins: 4 antoniniani, 2 sestertii; 1 medallion of bronze and gold and silver jewelry were found within a child grave: 4 antoniniani, 2 sestertii: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258).
The hoard was found in the northeast part of the Roman fort during an excavation campaign in 1983. It comprised 4 aurei and 70 denarii, ranging from Nero to Septimius Severus.
32 coins: 23 sestertii, 7 dupondii and 2 antoniniani (radiates): Titus - Postumus (AD 260-268).
All are imitations: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 116.4-203.9g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg

summary: c. 200 Alexandrian tetradrachms. 'Probably a whole hoard, offered for sale in Belgium.'
Circa 50 coins of silver and bronze. Only 36 were bought by the Museo Civico di Storia e Arte di Trieste: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Museo Civico di Storia e Arte di Trieste, Italy. Mixed with the rest of the coins in the museum collection

summary: Around 1,600 of which 1,168 identified: 1 Republican denarius of Mark Antony from 32–31 BC from the legionary series; 1,259 imperial denarii, 1 drachm, 5 imitations of imperial denarii: Nero - Macrinus (AD 217-218). Together with the coins was found a gold pendant.
The hoard comprised 14 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 260/1 and 270.
disposition: The University of Michigan Kelsey Museum of Ancient and Mediaeval Archaeology

summary: 21 antoniniani. T. Gerasimov saw 2 of Gordian III

12 coins found together in a pit that served as a cellar to an agricultural building. Probably were kept in a leather or fabric purse: 1 bronze medallion, 7 sestertii, 4 dupondii: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 240).
12 denarii: Marcus Aurelius - Septimius Severus (AD 201).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only three antoniniani (radiates) are known: Gordian III, Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (Gallienus), Postumus.
The hoard comprised between 600 and 700 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 210.9g and 874.1g.
6 coins: 4 bronze republican (!), 1 denarius Nero, 1 antoninianus (radiate) Aurelian (AD 270-275).
190 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 170 provincials: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 211-257

summary: At least 18 radiates (Gallienus to Tetricus I) found in the area of Tintern some time around 1872. It is uncertain that these represent the entirety of what might have been a hoard. No further information is available.
The hoard comprised nearly 1,500 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus to Probus, with coins of Probus being the most numerous. Only one coin of Gallienus' sole reign was described (RIC 599).

216 coins: 1 aureus, circa 200 silver and 13 bronze pieces: Galba to Valerian I (AD 253-260) found with a copper vessel, and inside was an envelope made up of two silver foils joined by very numerous and very small silver studs. Together were were found jewelry and tableware. Aurei including 1 of Galba. AR coins run from Vespasian to Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-260).
disposition: Musée d’Art et d’Histoire (MAH) de Genève, Switzerland

summary: The hoard comprised 50 antoniniani (radiates) from Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II.
8 coins: 5 double sestertii, 2 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 261-269).

in 1917, the museum received a small bronze container without lid that was said to have contained 18 coins (antoniniani, Gallienus to Tetricus), and probably found in Mainz-Kastel. The coins are lost.
Circa 2,000 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani from Vespasian to Trajan Decius. Mostly, Gordian III and Philip I. Found in a ceramic vessel.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 34 pieces eneterd the museum collection in Targovishte: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 46

summary: 61 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Found together with a bronze brooch.
disposition: Regional History Museum Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M IV 8346-8406

summary: 219 sestertii: Hadrian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253) found in a cooking pot covered with a bronze sheet.

The hoard was found in the south-eastern corner of Ulpia Traiana, south of the city walls and close to the Roman port. It comprised 46 sestertii, denarii and radiates from Trajan to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260 to 268.
55 antoniniani (radiates) : Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
100 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13604/1-100 (100 coins)

summary: On the eastern exterior of the late Roman NO-tower of the cathedral in Trier, a shaft for the protection of the tower foundation was laid out during maintenance work in 1980. The hoard was dug out in a depth of 5.20m. The 43 coins were soldered together in spherically formed clumps. The coins were originally preserved in a leather bag and lay on an antique stone floor.
Eight radiates declared Treasure Trove in 1980, otherwise unpublished. Not part of the Sprotbrough 1980 hoard.
The workers discovered a metallic vase with 20 kg of coins (maybe antoniniani). Only 214 are now recorded, from Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Gallienus) - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Berry Museum, St. Moritz, Switzerland (part of the hoard)

summary: Around 500 antoniniani (radiates). Only 96 coins were described: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

Coin hoard discovered during the construction of the airfield in Erding, south-east of Langengeisling. Close to the find spot ground walls of a villa rusticate were excavated in 1912. The hoard originally comprised ca. 300 denarii, of which only 96 could be traced (Hadrian - Maximinus I).
53 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Caracalla (Julia Domna ) (AD 211-217).
Mints are quantified but not allocated to issues. 28 Cologne, 15 Rome, 3 Milan: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
1889 antoniniani, 43 imitations, 6 forgeries and some fragments: Elagabalus - Probus (AD 276-282).
Unknown originally number of coins. According to I. Mira there are 2,842 coins known, all antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
disposition: Museo del Seminario de Santiago, Braga, Portugal (68 coins)

summary: Originally, 201 silver coins. 190 silver coins are documented: Hadrian - Carus (AD 282-285). The half follis of Justin I/Justinian I is, most likely, an intruder.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 165 (190 coins)

summary: 87 silver coins found in the "Ancient theater": Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
76 coins: 48 antoniniani (radiates), 28 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1938. Stolen

summary: The hoard comprised 26 coins, mostly large bronzes. 13 coins were broken. The others bear the portraits of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucilla. The 4 bronze coins of Postumus are cast and middle size (AD 264-265?).
disposition: Musée Saint-Jean, Angers, France (Reg. II, p. 184, no. 453 bis.)

summary: (55) 17 silver coins: 9 denarii, 8 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 21.6-34.1 g.

IARCH record for a scattered hoard of 6 denarii. Other coins have been recorded from the immediate area but they were not considered to be part of this hoard. For full details and images see SOM-D0A907.
1233 silver coins: 2 denarii, 1231 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 258).
More than 1,500 coins were discovered in a bowl. However, only 77 pieces are known in any detail, 5% of the original hoard: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).

A hoard of at least 202 radiates. The latest coin in the hoard is radiate of Gallienus (sole reign) from Milan mint dating to AD 262. Mint data exists for this hoard but TAF is not specific enough to allocate mints to rulers. Museum Inventory No: 75-7. Silver: 8, 223 coins; Silver weight: 71.8-592.1

The hoard comprised approximately 600 silver coins (denarii and radiates). The antoniniani (radiates) were described as being of 'large and medium module' according to Bocquillet. There were 38 different types from Commodus to Postumus Found during embankment works for the Château-l'Abbaye road.
7 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
(c. 100) 81: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver weight: 51.3-104.7 g.
The hoard comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) of Quietus (AD 260-261).
(700) 170 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Trajan - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268).

The hoard comprised 1,300 coins of which 21 from Philip I to Tacitus (AD 275-276) were acquired by C. Quandalle . These are not considered to be representative of the hoard as a whole, being either rare or issues that Quandalle did not have in his collection. Hobbs estimates a silver weight: c. 235.1-1624.1g.
67 antoniniani (radiates): 57 Gallienus (sole), 10 Salonina (AD 260-268).
disposition: Civiche Raccolte Numismatiche di Milano, Italy (inv.nos. M 999.08.1-M 999.08.67)

summary: The Wiggensbach hoard was discovered in 1889 in Waldegg. The hoard consists of jewellery, the quantity and typology of which is not described by FMRD, and silver coins, mostly denarii and at least 4 antoniniani, with coins ranging from Mark Antony to Severus Alexander. 384 of them were bought by the Heimatmuseum in Kempten. 25 remained in a private collection. A list of them exists, but it gives only the name of the emperor. FMRD speaks of 407 denarii, but lists only 401 coins among which a few antoniniani.
disposition: Allgäuer Heimatmuseum, Kempten, 25 specimens in private collections.

summary: 488 silver coins: 227 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 260 antoniniani: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania

summary: Hoard of initial of just over 100 aurei, 91 recovered (650 g = two Roman pounds): Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 231).
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Madrid (at the moment); Provincial Archaeological Museum of Cáceres, Spain (final destination)

summary: 1,486 tetradrahms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian (AD 295-296) in a disintegrated cloth bag on the floor of underground room J during excavations of a house.
6 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
77 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I
572 silver coins: 2 denarii, 570 antoniniani: Macrinus - Valerian I (AD 253 -259); Silver weight: 1143.8-2361.7g
1,103 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 296) found in a disintegrated cloth bag in an underground room during excavations of a house.
The hoard comprised 4 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander with a tpq of AD 228 to 234.
+100 coins dating from Philip I to Valerian and Gallienus. No catalogue was made and no further information given about the composition of the hoard.
Ten antoniniani of which one of Tacitus.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 156 silver coins: 147 denarii, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 247); silver weight: 198.8-366.5 g.

A hoard of 159 provincial bronze coins (Septimius Severus to Philip I) and 73 illegible coins, found at Dura Europos in a room of the Roman barracks (like hoard 14, though nothing indicated that these were part of the same hoard).

Four coins (Syracuse, Augustus, Tiberius for Agrippa and Severus Alexander), allegedly found in the bed of the River Weser at low tide, at 'der Tiefer'. FMRD has listed this find under Bremen-Mahndorf, but doubts that it is genuine.

The alleged content of a purse comprises 36 mixed denominations (radiates and sestertii) from Trajan to Carinus. The purse was originally located over an abandoned hearth within a taberna in the eastern sector of the so called domus of Titus Macer. Coins originate from different layers; two late Roman bronze coins have to be regarded as instrusions while the connection of a very worn repubblican denarius with the purse is uncertain.
disposition: Aquileia, Archaeological National Museum; University of Padua, department of Cultural Heritage

summary: 68-70 kg, 28-30000 antoniniani: Valerian I - Florian (AD 276); silver weight: 5221.1-36248.9 g (after Hobbs).
168 denarii and Antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

A hoard comprising 5 sestertii from Domitian to Macrinus. It has been interpreted as a purse or a small votive deposit. It was found on a hilltop above a cliff during metal detectorist's surveys (2002 and 2004).
1,937 antoniniani (radiates) found in a cooking pot: Caracalla - Postumus (AD 263).
Scarce Information on a hoard, in which circa 20 antoniniani depict portarits of seven emeperors between AD 238-268 from Gordian III to Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Museum of Sain-Sulpice, France, but no records of them in the registers.

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. Dr. Haralanov examined 468 silver coins: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised one bronze vessel containing 7150 radiates from Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius Gothicus, Aurelianus and Probus. It must be linked to the treasure LA VINEUSE II

1610 antoniniani and fragments of a ceramic vessel with lid: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282). The coins were minted in Siscia, Sirmium, Serdica and other mints. The majority of the coins belong to Gallienus and Claudius II. Due to poor condition of reservation 157 coins could not be identified; silver weight: 244.1-1686.4 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 2731-4172, 4319-4414; 1,538 coins

summary: 28 coins found in the Dionysos House: 1 sestertius, 22 provincial coins, 5 undocumented coins: Septimius Severus/Caracalla (Julia Domna) - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The coins were found in a stone sarcophagus along with some ashes. They comprised coins dating from the reign of Augustus (Altar of Lyon) to the reign of Maximinus (of Thrace?). The coins were found during the demolition of a tumulus.
Hoard of 216 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).
Roman Provincial coins: Thessalonica (1 Elagabalus, 1 Gordian III, 1 Otacilia Severa), Pella (2 Gordian III, 1 Otacilia Severa), found in a grave.
691 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 284-293). No further details.

The hoard comprised two or three ceramic urns filled with Roman coins, weighing approximately 5 kilos or perhaps 1,200 coins. Although the containers were broken up and the hoard dispersed, 762 coins were recovered in the days following the hoard's discovery, including 10 from the presumed findspot. They were all radiates from Gordian III to Claudius II and Postumus.
56 denarii: Mark Antony - Caracalla (AD 214); silver weight: 87.8-167.0g.
disposition: Voralberg Museum, Bregenz, (initial 51 coins, in 1977 46); Private collection, Innsbruck (1 coin), Austria

summary: Apparently more than 500 coins in this hoard.
Hoard found in a ceramic vessel consisting of 80 denarii. One denarius of Severus Alexander is known.
313 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Caracalla (Geta) (AD 211-212). 'Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".'
disposition: 'Selection in Oxford, where there is also a handwritten list (Milne); some of the rest are probably in Toronto'

summary: It comprised 23 coins found in "un grand mortier de pierre" (mortarium). Only 3 were identified: Augustus, Marcus Aurelius, Aurelian.
357 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius, ranging from Caracalla to Aemilian (AD 253); silver weight: 448.5-804.5 g.
disposition: Archives de la Commission d'assistance publique (358 coins); private collection (3 coins); Musée communal de Bruxelles"

summary: About 2000 antoniniani and 4 aurei up to AD 270.
A suspicious hoard as there is no evidence for the conditions of discovery, except one note in a local newspaper: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (Plautilla (AD 202-205).

The hoard comprised 372 coins that were fused together in a single lump. They comprised 1 denarius and 371 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Victorinus. The mint distribution is given in TAF (Rome: 210; Cologne: 93; Trier: 24) but not related to issues of particular emperors. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 100g to 111.0g.
1,100 or 1,000 coins found with a bronze vessel. and gold coins from Antoninus Pius to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

33 Alexandrian tetradrachms and a fragment of a bronze-ring. Found in a wooden jar in the courtyard just in front of a door during excavations of a house. Ranking: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293).
The total number of coins found is not known although it is suggested to be as 5,000 pieces. Only 251 coins kept in a local collection were studied. Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
43 kg = +8,000 silver coins: denarii and antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 258)
26 coins: 24 sestertii, 2 denarii: Trajan - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235); silver weight: 4.75 g.
disposition: Collection Ms. Ausselet, Charleroi, Belgium (26 coins and the lid)

summary: Four aurei and jewelrey: Trajan Decius - Gallienus (sole) found with a copper vessel. Some of the objects were taken by the finder. According to the finder, Near the vessel was a stone in a vertical position.
disposition: Institut d'Archéologie de Bucarest; Musée National d'Histoire de Bucarest; dispersed

summary: 339 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Silver: 254, 85 coins; silver weight: 69.6-316.5g.

494 coins found with a bronze vessel: 2 gold medallions, 6 aurei, 486 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Nero - Postumus (AD 260-269); gold weight: 63.6 g.; silver weight: 133.8-1515.2 g. The hoard was found by a farmer. The multiple of Gallienus was acquired by the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna.

7 (!), but only 6 coins mentioned found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian, Lucius Verus, Commodus 2, Trajan Decius and one unidentified coin. Together, it was found a bronze bar (59x16x 95 mm). Some doubts have been expressed about this discovery!
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120192: 1-8).

summary: The hoard comprised 73 denarii from Septimius Severus to Maximinus and 215 radiates from Pupienus to Valerian (AD 253-260). Hobbs estimated a silver weight of between 372.6-693.8g.

The hoard comprised a large earthenware vessel containing 1,100 bronze coins (for the most part sestertii) and 30 'small coins with surface silvering' (radiates). A summary catalogue of 200 of the best preserved examples was made by F. Homo. The hoard was found by workmen from the Letellier company during quarrying for stone. It was found at only a slight depth 'faible profondeur'.
The hoard was found in an iron box deposited under a mosaic depicting Bacchic themes and contained 40 coins of Gordian III to Postumus. The denominations of the coins were not specified.
This hoard comprised 3,727 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of c. AD 265-275.

Forger's hoard of 121 coinsand blanks (only two coins). The finder also found a fragment of copper alloy rod, a sherd of courseware pottery and a brooch. It is possible, but by no means certain that the hoard was secreted in a pot, but the surviving rim comes from a vessel much larger than was needed to contain the coins and other objects.
Unknown initial number of coins. 264 Roman provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9811-10060

summary: A hoard of Syrian tetradrachms (668 according to Coin Hoards, 666 according to Bland) ranging in date from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus. It is said to have been found at Iskenderun, 57 km north of Antioch.
The hoard comprised 110 denarii: Vespasian-Severus Alexander (AD 222-235 AD).
(5-6 kg) 2,000 coins. Identified 341 silver coins: 1 denarius, 340 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Valerian I (AD 259); silver weight: 2,500.2 - 4,759.1 g+.
disposition: Archeological Museum Zagreb (?980 coins); P. Broz collection Zagreb (83 coins), Croatia; dispersed - 1981

summary: 10 Alexandria tetradrachms: Probus-Maximianus I (AD 284-285).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Regionale "P. Orsi", Siracusa: inv: 51795-51804

summary: The hoard comprised close to 20,000 coins of which 490 were seen. These included issues of Saloninus, Gallienus and Postumus.
5,000 antoniniani (radiates) found with more ceramic pots. Only 2,249 were available for study: Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 272).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa; Museu Municipal do Bombarral; Museu Municipal Pedro Nunes, Alcácer do Sal, Portugal; private collection, Barcelona, Spain

summary: The coins were found in a cremation burial, mixed in with the cremated bone and ash. The coins comprised an as of Vespasian and 12 sestertii ranging from Domitian to Philip I.
6 tetradrachms of Alexandria found in a grave ranging from Probus to Constantine I.
13 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 216); silver weight: 24.9-37.2g.

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 900 coins of which 200 were dispersed. They included issues of Trajan, Plotina, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and II, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Lucilla, Commodus, Crispina, Clodius Albinus and Julia Domna. The cataloguer mentioned these coins in particular: one of Diva Faustina, 2 coins of Divus Antoninus Pius (RIC 1262/1265 and 1274) and one of Commodus with a quadriga on the reverse.
41 silver hoards: 2 denarii, 39 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus (Julia Maesa) - Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 260-268). The coins were found together in a small pit.
5 antoniniani without any certainty that they were part of a hoard: Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270).

The hoard comprised an amphora containing approximately 5,400 Roman coins, weighing 143 kilos in total. They were mostly sestertii with some 'middle bronzes' (asses, according to Hollard 1992, 99). Blanchet catalogued a selection of 132 from the collections of the Musée Carnavalet from Gordian III to Postumus Silver: 1, 50 coins; silver weight: 17.4-63.0g.
disposition: Musée Carnavalet, Paris (132 coins); Sanatorium Nestor Pirotte Angicourt (120 coins, possible lost)

summary: 54 antoniniani (radiates) found in a wall with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
156 silver coins: 11 denarii, 145 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus (Caracalla Caesar) - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 55.0-394.8g.

The hoard comprised one silver coin and 18 bronze coins dating from the 3rd c. AD, found close to Metsovo (BCH 1939). Touratsoglou mentions 18 sestertii (Maximinus Thrax - Gordian III), next to 1 denarius / antoninianus, with the find spot Anthochori. No further information available.
The hoard comprised 93 silver coins dated between AD 211-218.
447 coins found with a cooking pot, 447 antoniniani (radiates), 1 provincial bronze of Nicaea: Severus Alexander - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
A hoard of 45 antoniniani found in the burial of a soldier killed during the siege for Dura Europos in 256/7.

The hoard comprised approximately 1,000 antoniniani (radiates) of which only 604 coins were catalogued. TAF outlines the numbers of coins by emperor and by mint but the two sets of figures do not tally. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 116.4g and 1097.6g.
A hoard of 428 denarii dating from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus Thrax (235/236) and one Caesarean drachm of Septimius Severus found at Sulakyurt.
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara, Turkez

summary: 277 antoniniani (radiates) + 28 imitations antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation denarius: Valerian I and Gallienus for Saloninus (Caesar) - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
disposition: Musées royaux d'Art et d'Histoire - Koninklijk Musea voor Kunst en Geschiedenis (Brussels)

summary: 21 bronze coins,found with two pebbles and a bronze ring in the fill of the outer fort ditch. Found concreted together and later separated, probably a purse hoard although no traces of a container survived.

Within lumps, the coins were arranged in stacks shifted sideways, 389 silver coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates). All coins were covered with a light green patina. There are 88 denarii: Clodius Albius to Gordian III and 301 antoniniani (radiates): Macrinus Valerian I and Gallienus).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 'several hundred', '75kg' or 'approximately 3,000 sestertii from Domitian to Maximinus I Thrax. The entire hoard was quickly dispersed.
Unknown originally number of coins. 53 denarii were recovered in two lots: Vespasian – Gordian III (AD 238-244).
53 silver coins found with a purse in the fortress wall: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 243-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv. no. N 1229-1238

summary: (200+) 103 silver coins: 78 denarii, 25 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 246)
(c.700) 601 bronze coins: 598 sestertii (+ imitations), 2 dupondii, 1 as: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 262).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (37 coins); in 1959, 13 private collectors: 564 coins

summary: The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel and comprised 114 antoniniani (radiates). TAF comments that the presence of the coin of Magnia Urbica is very unusual. It questions whether this coin was added to the hoard after its discovery or whether the hoard was only part of a larger assemblage. The hoard was found in a hole surround by a large amount of masonry (possibly ancient) during the demolition of a fifteenth century building: . Silver: 113 coins; Silver weight: 31.5-140.3g.
Over 20 denarii. No further information.
The hoard consisted of two lots of 215 and 301 antoniniani (radiates): Balbinus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260). Only 299 coins were studied.
disposition: Civiche Raccolte Numismatiche del Comune di Milano; Gabinetto Numismatico dei Civici Musei di Pavia, Italy; private collection

summary: 4 coins of Gordian III: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 2 sestertii P M S COL VIM (AD 238-244).
The hoard was found in "Perron" locality, in a vase. It comprised 1,200 coins from Elagabalus to Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised two copper-alloy urns containing 515 Roman coins (denarii, antoniniani (radiates) and bronzes). The majority of the coins were well preserved. The division of the coins between the two urns was not recorded. The hoard was found while extracting limestone. Vespasian - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
101 coins: 16 denarii, 85 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight 122.1-240.8 g.
disposition: Regional Historical Museum, Vidin, Bulgaria; inv.no. 591

summary: Breakdown of mints is given suggesting that full breakdown is given in articles. Silver: 1406 coins; Silver weight: 40.1g
Around 50 antoniniani were discovered. Coins were issued by Gordian III, Philip I, Philip I for Otacilia Severa, and Valerian I (AD 253-259).
Group of 5 coins discovered in an ancient cellar: 4 double sestertii of Postumus, 1 imitation of antoninianus (radiate) of Victorinus (AD 269-271).
Approximately 130 silver coins, the majority of which were denarii, of which only a small proportion were identified.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 572 worn sestertii of the second century to Gordian III.
30 aurei and several hundred denarii and antoniniani up to mid-3rd century. The coins were found together with four golden rings with gems and a gold ingot.
775 denarii: Nero – Severus Alexander (AD 228).
Three coins of Postumus were found in the basement area of the hypocaust heating room inside the main building of a villa rustica located north-east of Niederzier, in the 'München Busch' wooded area.
Antoninus Pius to Trajan Decius: 350 silver coins; silver weight: 352.8-905.2g.

The hoard was found in a cave and comprised 60 Roman coin copies as well as numerous fragments of copper-alloy bar with Roman coin flans stamped on them. The hoard was interpreted as belonging to a forger.
6 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III 1, Philip I 4, Valerian I 1 (AD 258-259). Found with jewelry.
disposition: Museo Nazionale Romano, Medagliere, Rome (inv.nos. 516410-516415 coins; 517911-517915)

summary: 35 denarii: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231). There is no certainty that this was the total number of the monetary group. The owner could have retrieved part of the coins, as well as the following agricultural works, probably, led to the finding of other pieces.
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania

summary: 9042 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD: 257-259); silver weight: 11297.5 g. Approx. 300 unidentified badly preserved coins.
86 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised two separate parcels of coins concealed within a cist constructed with five bricks and covered with a silver embossed leaf. The first parcel comprised nearly 700 sestertii dating from Galba to Severus Alexander. The second parcel, wrapped in fragments of linen, comprised denarii and radiates from Trajan to Volusian.
44 silver coins: 16 denarii, 28 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 243-244); Silver weight: 57.8-100.7g
The hoard comprised 36 silver coins - antoniniani (radiates) - of Gordian III to Postumus and 6 copper-alloy coins from Trajan to Faustina II.
14 denarii (late Republic to Severus Alexander) were found in 1906 in front of the door sill of cellar 83 (in the Roman settlement).
500 provincial bronze coins. N. Mouchmov saw 6 of them: Marcianopolis: Septimius Severus 2, Macrinus 1, Elagabalus 1, Severus Alexander 1; Nicopolis ad Istrum: Macrinus 1
The hoard was concealed under three stone slabs. There was no evidence of a container.
A hoard of 50 coins found in a Roman building: 18 antoniniani (radiates), 4 denarii, 3 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 24 provincial bronzes: Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

A small bronze cauldron containing a linen bag with the coins. The money consists of 889 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus. Two pieces of silver-plated crockery, a plate and a platter, were found next to the cauldron.
250 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 10 coins have been seen by T. Gerasimov: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 22 silver coins from the reign of Macrinus (AD 217-218).

A hoard of ca. 2000 bronze coins was discovered in 1902 in Eleusis, a few metres east of the peribolos wall of the sanctuary, in the garden of a coffeehouse belonging to Georgios B. Adam. The hoard was divided into two lots, which were said to have been approximately equal in size. One of these was dispersed. The other, consisting of 972 specimens, was examined and catalogued by Svoronos 1904. It included 958 provincial coins from Athens (time of the Antonines and Gallienus), 1 provincial coin from Thessalonica, 1 from Argos and 12 sestertii (Hadrian à Gordian III).
2000 silver coins found during road repairing works: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Five antoniniani (radiates): Valentinian I and Gallienus - Postumus. Unknown circumstances of discovery.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing several thousand (more than 4,000?) coins from Septimius Severus to Postumus 'all in silver, with varying titles'. A list of numbers of types (rather than numbers of coins) exists. The coins were discovered 'by chance' in ancient ruins at the site. Silver: 4000+ (480) coins; Silver weight: 921.7-10397.2+
disposition: Musée d'Orbigny (20 coins), France; Musée de Guéret, France

summary: 2,484 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a jar in an underground room during excavations of a house.

The hoard originally comprised 50.591 antoniniani: Gordianus III - Maximian I ( AD 293). Almost the whole hoard was acquired and now 45.873 coins are kept in the Museo di Castelvecchio, Verona. This find is extensively published. 168 kilos.
disposition: Verona, Museo di Castelvecchio, 45873 coins; otherwise dispersed

summary: 108 antoniniani: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 265-266); silver weight: 26.4-195.3 g.
A large ceramic vessel containing 15 kg of silver coins. 4453 antoniniani were published (Moushmov 1936): Aemilian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXIX (in 1925); 1,231 coins

summary: 15 provincial bronzes found during the salvage excavation at Zeugma in 1998, on the floor of a house. The report in Coin Hoards mentions '15 AE of Zeugma in the names of Gordian III, Philip I and Philip II'. However, there are no coins of Zeugma issued under Gordian III, so these must belong to a different mint.
11 provincial bronzes issued in Rhesaena by Trajan Decius and his family, found in destruction deposits of Room 9J.
27 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 35.6-71.4 g.
40 silver coins: 5 denarii, 35 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 258-259).
96 denarii found with a ceramic pitcher: Republic – Septimius Severus (AD 201-210).
disposition: History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (91 coins); Cultural room, Ardeoani (4 coins); High-school ”Vasile Alecsandri”, Bacău (1 coin)

summary: The hoard comprised 287 denarii: 93 republican, 194 imperial: Republic - Caracalla (AD 215).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles, Paris, France; collection Favre

summary: Few hundreds denarii. 14 pieces entered the museum collection in Stara Zagora: Faustina II 1, Septimius Severus 5, Julia Domna 2, Geta 2, Caracalla 3, Maximinus I Thrax 1.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3520-3525

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 7 silver coins seen by T. Gerasimov: 2 denarii, 5 antoniniani: Severus Alexander - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 10.4-17.2 g.

There are two different notes regarding hoards found in this area in the 1880s. The author argues that the notes relate to the same hoard. A) A bronze vase containing silver coins of the third century AD was found in Sardoal. 12 of these coins were acquired by the Ethnographic Museum. B) The Ethnographic Museum in Abrantes acquired 190 silver coins dating to the third century AD, which formed part of a hoard found in Sardoal in the 1880s.
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 108 antoniniani (radiates)Ș Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270).

Unknown number of coins. Few coins are mention in the collection of Reydet de la Vulpillière, which indicate a large diversity of coins, denarii, antoninaini, sestertii, from Republic to Tacitus (AD 276)
100-200 silver coins. Only 4 coins are known: 1 denarius, 3 antoniniani: Septimius Severus (Caracalla) - Gordian III (AD 241-243).

The hoard comprised a vessel containing 94 bronze coins, of which 82 were examined. They included 2 sestertii and 80 double sestertii of Postumus, mostly LAETITIA AVG, VICTORIA AVG and FIDES MILITVM reverse types. Tpq AD 266-267
The hoard comprised 5 silver denarii from Septimius Severus to Elagabalus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 9.2g.
18 provincial bronze coins found in a small ceramic vessel. 16 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2677, 16 coins

summary: Unknown Initial number of coins. 1509 silver coins: 1,486 denarii, 6 plated denarii, 17 antoniniani (radiates) Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 244). Silver weight: 4,710 g. Around 30 coins are still missing
disposition: Muzeul Regiunii Porților de Fier, Drobeta-Turnu Severin (1,502 coins); Muzeul Olteniei, Craiova (7 coins), Romania

summary: 4,128 coins found in two vessels: 3 denarii, 4,125 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 252).

A hoard of at least 121 denarii and antoniniani (Septimius Severus - Valerian I), found by two metal detectors in 2006. Some coins were preserved in fragmentary form and these fragments could account for another 1-3 specimens.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 275 sestertii and dupondii or asses, arranged in piles from Domitian to Gordian III. Two thirds of the hoard were unidentifable because of a thick layer of corrosion products. The hoard was found in a wood on the Tesnières wood in the roots of an oak tree. Fragments of the ceramic vessel and part of the hoard were acquired by the Musée du Mans
3503 radiates to Probus, in a pot. Full identifications of all the coins of Probus is unavailable. Unpublished?
A hoard of 233 Alexandrian tetradrachms, ranging from Nero to Philip, found 1968 in Abu al-Gud, in the vicinity of Luxor.
It comprised c. 400 silver coins. Only 149 are now recorded: 148 antoniniani (radiates), 1 denarius: Septimus Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole).
809 silver coins: 91 denarii, 718 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) - Valerian I (AD 258). Found with two ceramic vessels.
Hoard of 109 gold stateri of Sauromates II found during the excavations (AD 205-206)
The hoard comprised 8 dupondii, ranging from Titus to Gordian III (AD 241-244).
The hoard comprised 39 sestertii from Vespasian to Julia Domna, 4 denarii from Septimius Severus to Severus Alexander and 7 radiates from Gordian III to Otacilia Severa with a tpq of AD 248 to 249.

The hoard comprised a mass of coins which were concreted together. It is estimated that there were as many as 5,000. However, only 130 examples were cleaned. These were found to be of the emperors Gallienus and Probus.
403 antoniniani (radiates) and 34 imitations: Valerian - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
40 silver coins: Nerva - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
Over 2,897 antoniniani (radiates): Treboninaus Gallus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Landesmuseum Joanneum, Graz, Austria (for restoration work - in 1977)

summary: (746) 668 denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253)
Around 1,200 antoniniani (radiates) found with amphoras on a shipwreck. 229 coins were studied: Gallienus (sole) - Maximian I (AD 284-293).

The hoard comprised two separate deposits. The first contained 28 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Postumus. The second contained 622 radiates from Philip I to Victorinus with a tpq of AD 270. The circumstances of discovery means that a clear relationship between the two hoards cannot be established with any certainty.

Small hoard of 15 ant. of Gallienus to Tetricus II, from 'Dover General Deposits', reported on by Peter Curnow & Richard Reece, all show evidence of wear, majority clipped.Reece, R. 2012. The Roman coins. In B. Philp The Discovery and Excavation of the Roman Shore-fort at Dover, Kent. Kent Archaeological Monographs 11. Kent Archaeol. Rescue Unit, pp. 108.
The hoard comprised one ceramic jug and two urns (?) containing 90 kg of coins. 2,777 antoniniani are known: Divus Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Circonscription archéologique de la ville de Souk Ahras

summary: Rescue excavation undertaken by the archaeological service. 20 antoniniani and 3 denarii, ranging from Caracalla to Gallienus (sole reign) were found.
Unknown initial number of coins. 70 pieces are kept in the museum of Lovech: 12 denarii, 29 antoniniani, 29 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Aemilian (AD 253).
disposition: Museum of Lovech, department of Archaeology, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1675-1676

summary: 500 antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. 243 were published: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
(619) 607 silver coins: 1 republican denarius, 235 imperial denarii and 371 antoniniani: M. Antony to Trajan Decius (AD 249-250); silver weight: 775.8-2053.0 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 13

summary: The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 368 coins including denarii and sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius and Provincial bronzes of the Koinon of Thessaly from Marcus Aurelius to Maximinus I. It was accompanied by some pieces of gold jewellery.
disposition: Éphorie des antiquités préhistoriques et classiques de Larissa

summary: Originally 164 coins, only 45 were identified: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 299).

A very large hoard of approximately 25 or 30,000 coins (Severus Alexander - Gallic Empire, probably Victorinus), found in Friedrich-Wilhelm-Strasse. The coins were dispersed. 907 of them are listed in FMRD, in six different lists according to the place where the coins are kept today: 1) 595 coins in the RLMT Trier (FMRD 3064,3) 2) 54 coins in the RLMT Trier, with mention 'probably from that hoard' (FMRD 3064,4) 3) 41 coins bought by the RLMT Trier in 1925 from a private collector (FMRD 3064,5) 4) 30 coins in the RGM Köln (FMRD 3064,6) 5) 1 coin in private coll. (FMRD 3064,7) 6) 186 coins bought by the archaeological Museum in Zagreb in 1906/7 (FMRD 3064,8)
disposition: RLMT Trier; RGM Köln; private collection Lückger, Germany; Archaeological Museum, Zagreb, Croatia

summary: 131 silver coins: 19 antoniniani, 112 denarii found with an urn: Antoninus - Gordian III (AD 242-244). Some scholars also mention gold coins.
disposition: Münzkabinett Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien (6 coins); Landemuseum Joanneum, Graz (72 coins); Institut für Alte Geschichte, Universität Graz

summary: The hoard comprised 4 coins of Severus Alexander (AD 222-235) and 2 unidentified coins.

The hoard comprised 'an earthenware vessel filled with 652 silver and billon coins (denarii and radiates) and 100 bronzes (sestertii and dupondii or asses). The silver and billon coins weighed 3.7kg. A further 186 coins were offered for sale in Rouen in 1971 and appear to be from the same hoard.' The coins were deposited at the Bibliothèque municipale de Rouen, where 168 examples were actually conserved and catalogued by Mme J. Delaporte. Archives Inventory No. 2-653.
disposition: Bibliothèque municipale de Rouen (Archives Inventory No. 2-653)

summary: 167 silver coins: 97 denarii, 70 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Diocletian (AD 295).
disposition: formerly Regional museum Tiel (destroyed during WWII)

summary: Hoard of 21 coins - 6 denarii and 15 counterfeits. Pit also contained broken samian & coarseware pottery and an iron hook, possibly a mount for a purse. Pit found during southern vicus excavs. S of River Tees, to W of the N-S road (Holme House 71-2).

Coins run from Mark Antony to Trajan Decius, although it has been argued that the last coins could be intrusive. In that case, the hoard would end with issues of Gordian III. 81,096 (and not 81,044!) coins were published in 1934 by Mouchmov, after a further 20,000+ coins had been dispersed. The total number of coins therefore exceeds 101,096 specimens. The difference between our comput and the 81,044 coins mentioned in the original publication resides in an error in counting the number of coins of Commodus (3146, whereas 3191 is correct) and reporting the correct number of coins of Caracalla in the table p. 6 of Mouchmov's publication. Note that further errors have occurred for Trajan (p. 21, last three entries, where numbers do not add up).
disposition: National Museum, Sofia (ca. 68,783 coins). Archaeology Museum, Varna, Bulgaria: inv.nos. 2807-2829, 4301-16363 (12,261 coins: Nero - Gordian III)

summary: The hoard comprised 50 sestertii from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. It was found on the Arcellier property, but dispersed almost immediately.

Around 1910 a hoard with 423 Antoniniani was salvaged during excavation of a building pit. The find spot ('auf den Kästrich') could not be further circumscribed, so that it is uncertain whether the deposit was found inside or outside of the legionary camp. The find is said to have been found with leather remnants in an earthenware container.
The hoard comprised 2,118 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian with a tpq of AD 270 to 275.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1991-214/1 - jug; 2:1 - 2120

summary: The hoard comprised between 400 and 500 radiates: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) for Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The hoard was discovered during antiquarian exploration of a Gallo-Roman site. It appeared to have been originally stored in a cabinet measuring 6 feet square and comprised more than 300 base-silver coins. According to the finder, villagers who knew the findspot continued to find coins in abundance there. 300 silver coins: Severus Alexander - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268); silver weight: 76.1-710.8+g.
24 large bronze cooins (sestertii and double sestertii?): Domitian - Postumus (AD 260-268).
30 kg of coins: Valerian I, Gallienus, Vlaudius II, Tetricus I. 369 have been seen by D. Nony: Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
431 coins: 295 denarii, 136 antoniniani: Commodus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 253); silver weight: 584.0-1024.5 g.

Unknown initial number of coins. The hoard comprised 1,068 denarii and two asses dating from Nero to Balbinus and Pupienus with a tpq of AD 239. The hoard has a silver weight of between 1496.9g and 3341.1 g.
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca, Romania

summary: (160) 130 silver coins: 129 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 239); silver weight: 181.8-353.2 g.

The hoard comprised several hundred coins of which only 150 were catalogued. They included a dupondius of Marcus Aurelius, a denarius of Plautilla, a few denarii and radiates of Caracalla, Geta, Elagabalus and Maximinus, numerous radiates of Gordian III, as well as Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus, Aemilian, Valerian I and II, Saloninus, Salonina, numerous examples of Gallienus, and some of Postumus.
The hoard originally comprised an undetermined amount of denarii: Domitian - Elagabalus (AD 218-222 ). Only 42 coins are now available.
165 coins (163 denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from Domitian to Alexander Severus), found with 2 silver bracelets ca. 3 km east of the Römerstraße. The coins were destroyed during the war.
disposition: Staatliche Münzsammlung München (lost during WWII; one bracelet survived)

summary: "Few hundreds", only 89 were seen: Balbinus - Maximian I (AD 294).
disposition: Collection P. du Chatellier; Musée de Bretagne, Rennes, France (inv.no. MAN 80313, 54 coins)

summary: Funerary find. 'A large number of coins finds' between large Stone blocks. Near the place were found human bones and funerary inventory. The 30 coins analyzed revealed antoniani of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus and Claudius II (AD 268-270). No further Information.
disposition: Society of Natural History Savoie (30 coins)

summary: The hoard comprises 32 antoniniani (radiates) from Aurelian to Numerian). The first publication by Taracena notes 1 coin of Aurelian and 2 of Numerian. However, Gurt notes 2 examples of Aurelian and 1 of Numerian.
Six or seven? aurei found in grave no. 3: Gordian III 2, Philip I 3 (AD 244-249) and possibly Hostilian 1 with a drachm of Gotarzes II and 3 denarii of Augustus found during excavations.
Large hoard of silver coins. Only 5 pieces are known: Aurelian 2, Tacitus 1, Probus 2; silver weight: 1.0-1.4g.

A small hoard of 45 radiates in a pot dating "to within a few years of AD 280" (Pastscape 343603) found during archaeological excavations of a Roman settlement in the Weedon Road area by Northamptonshire's Archaeological Unit in the 1970s.
20 antoniniani of the 3rd century AD were find during metal detecting activity. No further information
This hoard comprised 4,000 coins from Gallienus to Probus (with many imitations). It was found at the Hameau des Boulins. 3,219 coins are now at the Museum of Clamecy.

A hoard of 1,702 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Clodius Albinus to Trebonnianus Gallus, found in the surroundings of Düren approx. 15 years before 1930 when it was published. It is not sure that the 1,702 coins listed there encompass all the coins that were originally part of the hoard.
The hoard comprised approximately 70 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus (AD 260-269). Forty-four coins are catalogued.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel (amphora?). 38 denarii were avalable for study: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I Diva) - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
IARCH record for a small hoard of 10 radiates. Possibly associated with the Chalgrove II hoard (IARCH-CB9058) but recorded separately due to uncertainty over this association.
60 silver and bronze coins found by workers 19 provincial bronze coins were aquired by the Varna Archaeological Society: Gordian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
495 silver coins: 1 denarius, 488 antoniniani (radiates): Augustus, Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 135.3-612.6 g.
Unknown originally number of coins. 49 denarii recovered: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 223); silver weight: 70.2-143.0 g.
Hoard of 198 coins of the Bosporan kings, Rhescuporis V, Pharsanzes, Sauromates IV, Teiranes (AD 266-278).
100 sestertii found together on an opus signinum floor: Hadrian - Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) (AD 251-253).
6 uncertain imperial coins (Vespasian-Aurelian).

The hoard comprised a ceramic pot containing 60 silver and billon coins. Joullietton noted the presence of coins of Otacilia Severa ('some'), Gallienus, Saloninus and Postumus ('a large number') of which many possessed the reverse type HERC DEVSONIENSI (E. 316) The hoard was found by a farmer cutting down a cherry tree in his garden.

A container with possibly 3000 antoniniani (Valerian - Quintillus) found in the Schwarzbruch forest close to Orscholz. The coins were dispersed, but 2842 were described. 619 were given to the Rheinisches Landesmuseum in Trier where 227 coins could still be traced.
Hoard of circa 60 antoniniani (radiates) with coins from Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II (AD 268-270).
The hoard comprised 2 radiates and 17 Provincial coins (Thessalonica, Edessa and Koinon of Macedonia), found in Koufalia.
1170 silver coins: M. Aurelius - Philip I; Silver weight: 1463.8-3029.0 g.

Before 1939, an archaeologist bought a hoard comprising 2,065 antoniniani (radiates) from a clerk in Évron. The hoard appears to have come from the north of the département, perhaps Aron or Évron, or, according to Cordonnier is another hoard from Jublains: Trajan Decius - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
14 silver coins, 13 known: 12 antoniniani (radiates) 1 denarius: Septimius Severus - Carinus (AD 283-285); silver weight: 4.2-33.3 g.

The hoard was found in a vessel and comprised approximately 2,000 antoniniani (radiates), with the majority being Gallienus, Postumus and 'some other Gallic emperors' 'The hoard was found on the ground surface during flint extraction in the triage du Parc, around 2 km from the village in the Breteuil forest.' There appears to be an error with this findspot description as the triage du Parc is 8 km from Breteuil and is in the village of Bémécourt.
7 denarii undescribed (Vespasian - Severus Alexander) found in fortifications.
The hoard comprised 93 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus with a tpq of AD 282.

1918 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian - Victorinus (AD 271); mints: 1006 Rome, 787 Mediolanum, 122 Cologne, 1 Siscia, 1 Viminacium, 1 Antioch: Valerian I and Gallienus - Cludius II/Victorinus (AD 268-271); silver weight: 518.8-2396.6 g.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 400 Roman sestertii from Nerva or Trajan to Postumus. 77 coins were examined.
872 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver weight: 632.6-2244.5g
229 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Museum of Pavia, Coin Room (inv.nos. 4.54, 4.59, 4.82, 4.101-4.866 not always in sequential order)

summary: Around 1,000 antoniniani found with a ceramic jug: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
109 silver coins: 6 denarii, 103 antoniniani: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 247-248).
57 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-254).
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest; Museum Dunaújváros, Hungary

summary: The hoard comprised 60 silver coins, almost all of Gallienus (AD 253-268).
The hoard comprised 31 sestertii from Vespasian to Commodus, 1 dupondius of Caracalla and 281 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 351.8g to 729.5g
The hoard was found in small red brick 'ampoule' in a grave next to a skeleton. It comprised 307 radiates from Valerian I to Victorinus with a tpq of AD 270.
Unknown originally number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Three coins are known: Hadrian denarius, Septimius Severus denarius, Philip I antoninianus (radiate).
A hoard containing, thus far, 121 denarii. The first coins were found in the 1950's, and the rest through excavation and metal detectoring until 2017.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 150 third century antoniniani (radiates.) The hoard was discovered by a farmer while cutting back an oak tree.
1,764 coins, probably antoniniani (radiates), found with two ceramic vessels: Valerian I - Diocletian and Maximian I (AD 284-293).
8 coins of Tetricus I, including some imitations, located in the museum of Bad Dürkheim and allegedly found 1854 in an urn. This could be a hoard, or part of one, or a grave find.
100 provincial bronze coins found in a bronze vessel. 39 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 12089 (39 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 460 silver coins. Auvray mentions Gordian III, Philip, Trajan Decius, Volusian, Trebonianus Gallus and Valerian. In 1834, Pesche compiled a more complete catalogue. His source (although he does not acknowledge it) appears to be a manuscript held by the Sociétè d'Agriculture which describes Roman coins found in the city of Le Mans and its environs. Pesche adds to his catalogue coins of Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus, Lucilla and Pupienus. It is not clear whether these coins are part of the hoard. Silver: c.460 (1, 173) coins; silver weight: c. 576.7-1295.1g.

In the summer of 1935, a third, smaller, hoard composed of 59 antoniniani from Gallienus to Probus was found in Edlington among the rocks known as the Crags. Some fragments of a native calcite-gritted jar, found near the coins, may have formed their container. One coin of Salonina and one of Tetricus II were found some time after the main hoard, but clearly belonged to it.
